Oral Answers to Questions

Page: 438

Singaporean Women Detained by Malaysian Immigration Officers

(Update on investigations)

1 Mr Ang Wei Neng asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs (a) if he would provide an update on the results of the investigation that Singapore has received on the case involving two Singaporean women detained in Malaysia in June this year for alleged immigration offences and who were made to perform nude squats; (b) what is the number of Singaporeans caught by Malaysian authorities for not having their passports "stamped" by Malaysian immigration officers at the Malaysian side of the Woodlands and Tuas Checkpoints in the last three years.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr K Shanmugam) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I understand and share the concerns Singaporeans have over the treatment of the two Singaporean women. They were detained temporarily at the Pekan Nenas Detention Depot for alleged immigration offences.

We have raised these concerns officially with the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs on a number of occasions. They have assured us that they will investigate the allegations and that the outcome of the investigations would be conveyed to Singapore as soon as they are in. We have reminded them of this commitment, and in their last correspondence with us on the matter on 9 September 2011, the Malaysian High Commission in Singapore informed us that a thorough investigation of the case had been completed but that the report of the investigation was being finalised by the Malaysian Attorney-General's Chambers.

We are all aware of recent media reports that the Malaysian Minister of Home Affairs has made a statement on this case to the Malaysian Parliament. He was reported as having said that based on a probe, the female Malaysian immigration officer had carried out the body search on the two Singaporean women in an orderly manner, and that the inspection was according to that stated under the Detention Depot's Standard Operating Procedure. We have sought a clarification from both the Malaysian High Commission in Singapore and the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs about the statement because as far as we are aware, the investigations had not yet been concluded. The Malaysian High Commission informed us that it did not have any further information on the Malaysian Minister of Home Affairs' statement in the Malaysian Parliament and that his Ministry would be seeking an update from the Malaysian Attorney-General's Chambers on the status of the investigation. He added that the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs will provide us with the official report of the investigation as soon as it has been finalised. That is where things stand at this point in time.

Page: 439

I know that many Singaporeans are anxious for an expeditious resolution to this case. So are we. We have registered our concerns with our Malaysian counterparts and reminded them of their commitment to conduct a thorough investigation and update us on the outcome of those investigations. We will continue to press for the official investigation report. But even as we do this, it is important to bear in mind that this matter will have to be resolved in accordance with Malaysian laws, rules and regulations.

Mr Ang has also asked for the number of Singaporeans whose passports were not stamped at Malaysian Immigration checkpoints and had thus encountered difficulties on exit. The ICA does not keep track of such incidents because unless they are reported to us, we will not know about them. We have received very few such reports, but certainly not all such incidents are reported to either ICA or MFA. I will take this opportunity to remind Singaporeans travelling to Malaysia, and in particular those travelling to Johor by road, to always check and ensure that their passports are stamped at entry and exit by the Malaysian Immigration authorities.

Mr Ang Wei Neng (Jurong) : Sir, I thank the Minister for his comprehensive reply. I trust the Minister would agree that this incident will not affect the good bilateral relationship that we have with Malaysia. But having said that, when Singaporeans are detained at the Causeway for not getting their passports stamped, the experience can be traumatic. This is especially so when the Singaporeans just want to spend their holiday or conduct business in Malaysia without any intention to flout immigration rules. My question is: how can Singaporeans obtain help from the Government if they are detained at the Causeway for not getting their passports stamped, assuming that they are able to contact their family members or associates during their detention?

Mr K Shanmugam : This incident should not have an impact on the overall bilateral relationships between Malaysia and Singapore though we have made very clear that we want a proper investigation of the matter. We have conveyed our serious concerns when the original report came out and we have indicated that we will be looking at the report that comes to us very carefully. And that has been acknowledged by Malaysia. As regards Mr Ang's second point as to how Singaporeans who get detained in Malaysia for these sorts of offences can get help, on the basis that the detentions take place in accordance to established rules and procedure in the first place, the detainees will have a right to notify their next-of-kin. And insofar as Ministry of Foreign Affairs, our Consulate in Johor or other authorities get to know about it, we will certainly investigate, process and take up with the Malaysian authorities.

Page: 440

Impact of Floods in Thailand on Singapore's Rice Imports

2 Mdm Foo Mee Har asked the Minister for Trade and Industry in view of the severe floods in Thailand which had destroyed rice crops (a) what is the impact on our rice prices; (b) how dependent is Singapore on rice imports from Thailand; (c) what strategies are in place to keep rice affordable especially for the low income groups; and (d) how much rice stockpile does Singapore have.

The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Lee Yi Shyan) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry) : Sir, as of September 2011, the export price of Thai fragrant rice preferred by Singaporeans had risen by about 9% compared to the start of the year. Singapore's rice imports comprise only a small proportion of global rice exports. In 2010, our total volume of rice imports was only about 1% of the total rice traded in the world. Although about half of our rice imports in 2010 came from Thailand, it was less than 2% of Thailand's total rice exports. Given our small import volumes, we are a price taker. However, it would also mean our demand can be easily met by alternative sources of supply given the size of the world market.

This said, when prices of rice increase in the international market, our purchases will become more expensive too. While we cannot avoid price fluctuations, we can do a number of things to mitigate sharp price spikes and possible supply disruptions.

Firstly, we continue to diversify our supply sources. More than ever before, we now import rice from many more sources, including Vietnam, India and the United States. Our small import volume also helps ensure that we can source enough rice to meet demand.

Secondly, we maintain a policy of stockpile. Today, all of our rice importers keep a healthy stockpile of two months or more.

Thirdly, to better educate consumers, MTI through the Retail Price Watch Group (RPWG) is working with major supermarket chains and retailers to highlight the variety of rice, meaning apart from fragrant rice, available that are high in taste and quality; as well as other non-rice staples that consumers can consider as part of their healthy diet choice. Even with the Thai fragrant rice, there is a 1.5 times price differential between the branded and non-branded rice. MTI will continue to monitor the situation in Thailand with our importers and retailers to ensure supply and price stability.

Mdm Foo Mee Har (West Coast) : I thank the Minister of State for his comprehensive answer. I would like to ask a supplementary question on reports that financial speculators have been responsible for increases in global food prices. In the market, there has been discussion about spiralling – food prices being driven by financial players taking over the commodities market. Financial speculators now account for as much as 60% of the agricultural futures and options. Could the Minister of State also comment about how we are impacted and hedged against this?

Mr Lee Yi Shyan : Sir, I thank the Member Ms Foo Mee Har for her question. The kind of speculation that Ms Foo mentioned has not been seen at least in the contractual purchases between our importers and the exporters of the supplying countries. Typically, our importers will sign contracts of two to three months each time they place an order. In the last few months, when Thailand raised the rice prices, we are seeing our importers and importers in the market switching to lower cost supply. There is no panic in the market because this industry of supply has got many buffers in each of the supply chains. For instance, we have our own stockpile. Other countries do as well. Even the suppliers or the intermediaries themselves keep a healthy stock level in terms of supply. So, given the floods in Thailand, about 10% of the rice-growing areas in Thailand are affected. The other 90% is still supplying. In fact, we are all watching the harvest of fragrant rice in November.

Page: 441

Apart from fragrant rice – which accounts for only 18% of Thailand's rice production – the other 82% is in the white rice category. White rice has three to four harvests per year. First of all, we believe that the floods have not seriously affected the rice fields in Thailand. Secondly, given the frequency of harvesting, they will be able to catch up to re-supply to the market.

The market right now is quite calm. On the local scene, we have 35 major importers, supplemented by about 70 smaller importers who purchase rice from the smaller markets like India and Pakistan. We have sufficient competition within the local scene to ensure price stability.

Page: 441

Home-based Care for the Aged

3 Mr David Ong asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) whether there is sufficient support for home-based care of the aged, chronically ill or disabled elderly; and (b) what are the Ministry's plans to ensure that domestic help receive the right level of care-giver training and support to look after the elderly at home.

The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mdm Halimah Yacob) (for the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports) : Sir, MCYS understands and supports older Singaporeans' wish to age in place in their own homes among their loved ones, rather than in an institution among strangers and unfamiliar surroundings. We recognise the fact that our population is ageing rapidly and we need to prepare for this silver tsunami. Over the last few months, I have been visiting many eldercare facilities, including the frail elderly at home using home-based care services, to understand their needs and concerns. I agree that we need to do more.

Currently, MCYS and the Centre for Enabled Living (CEL) work with nine VWO service providers to offer home care to some 2,000 seniors. MCYS and CEL will nurture our VWOs so that they can expand and scale up their services in tandem with our rapidly ageing population. CEL will work with them on their manpower needs, and also to recruit and train the staff that they need. CEL will also continue to encourage and seed fund the use of technology and innovative care solutions to enhance the efficiency and quality of home care. The SEED Fund or Sustainable Enhancement for Eldercare and Disability Care Services Fund has, to date, supported 23 projects, granting a total of $2.4 million for initiatives benefiting our frail elderly and their caregivers.

One such initiative is the one that CEL is currently partnering with NTUC Eldercare and Thye Hua Kwan Moral Society, to pilot an integrated home care model. The pilots currently serve 184 elderly with multiple care needs. The staff takes care of the elderly's basic needs such as basic maintenance exercises, the provision of emotional support, personal hygiene, meals preparation and household tasks, in an ensuite elderly client-centric fashion.

Page: 442

Currently, home healthcare forms a small part of MOH's healthcare system. In 2010, there were 10 subvented home medical/nursing providers serving 4,000 unique patients. This includes a provider that has since ceased operations. MOH will of course continue to scale up the capacity and capability of this sector to meet the rising demand.

MOH has also started on several pilots to enhance home healthcare services. One such pilot is with the Home Nursing Foundation (HNF). HNF works with the hospital team to facilitate a smooth transition for patients newly discharged from the hospital to home. Once the patient is at home, HNF will coordinate with other service providers to provide for the patient's care needs in the community. HNF has served over 300 patients since its inception in August 2010.

MCYS and MOH are currently studying the provision of home based social and health care needs for our frail elderly, with a view to promoting ageing in place, right siting of care and a more seamless transition from hospitals to the community and the home.

On the issue of training for foreign domestic workers, MCYS recognises that they play an important role in supporting families to cope with the demands of caregiving. We introduced the Caregiver Training Grant in 2007. Families may use the grant to train their Foreign Domestic Workers (FDWs) to acquire core care skills. Between January 2010 and September 2011, 2,311 informal caregivers of our frail elderly had benefited from the grant, almost half of whom are FDWs.

CEL has partnered NTUC Eldercare to offer structured hands-on training for FDWs, including training on communication skills with the elderly, given the potential language barrier between our elderly and the FDWs. CEL is also partnering TOUCH to implement in-home training of FDWs which allows for customisation based on individual household needs. Since the start of the pilot training programmes in April 2010, 300 FDWs have been trained by NTUC Eldercare and TOUCH.

MCYS would like to encourage more employers to send their FDWs for training which will benefit both the frail elderly and the caregiver, as the numbers that have attended are still small. Caregivers need to have some basic skills so that they can provide better care to the elderly, as well as minimise physical and emotional stress and strains on themselves.

We believe that everyone can do their part to make ageing in place, meaning in the community and at home, a reality for our elderly. And MCYS will do our best to initiate and support these initiatives so that our frail elderly too can live in peace and with dignity in the twilight years of their lives.

Mr David Ong (Jurong) : On the training programme for caregivers including domestic help, the take-up rate as the Minister of State mentioned earlier is low. This could also mean that they are not aware or they have no time. Sir, I would like to see whether MCYS could work with MOM to look at accessibility of maids, and to see if we can have a training programme for them even before they are deployed to the homes. If the maids are not physically and mentally able to take care of the elderly, transitional care and other costs can be high.

Page: 443

Mdm Halimah Yacob : I want to thank Mr David Ong for the suggestion. It is a very useful suggestion and we would certainly look into it and work with Ministry of Manpower to see how we could do that. I agree entirely with Mr Ong that it would be better for us to prepare a FDW who is coming in for the specific purpose of taking take care of a frail elderly beforehand rather than after the person has already been employed and then gets caught up with her work, household chores as well as other care-giving responsibilities. It is a lot harder to pull the FDW out to go for training. We will look into his proposal and work to see how we could achieve that.

Page: 443

Use of Medisave Funds to Pay for Parents' Healthcare Expenses

4 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Health what percentage of Singaporeans currently draw from their adult children's Medisave accounts to pay for their own healthcare expenses.

The Minister for Health (Mr Gan Kim Yong) : Sir, in 2010, there were around two million working Singaporean CPF members, of which 80,000, or less than 5%, used their CPF to pay for their parents' healthcare expenses. If we exclude older CPF members from the denominator, the proportion will be slightly higher, but it will still be around 5%. A total of $732 million was withdrawn from Medisave accounts in 2010 to pay for direct medical expenses. Of this amount withdrawn, 18% was withdrawn to pay for the parents' treatment. Out of the total amount of Medisave withdrawn for the elderly's healthcare expenses last year, about 45% was from their children's Medisave accounts.

Sir, family support is an integral part of our healthcare financing framework. It is also an important second line of defence. But MOH is mindful of the burden and the responsibility borne by the younger generation in supporting the healthcare expenses of their elderly parents. The Government has from time to time provided top-ups to the Medisave accounts of the elderly. Between 2005 and 2011, nearly $1 billion was distributed to elderly Singaporeans this way. Workfare also helps older, low-income workers build up their Medisave by providing additional contributions over and above the normal CPF contribution rates. Nevertheless, I believe more can be done to help the elderly, especially those in the lower and middle-income families, and we are exploring ways to help them.

Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song (Non-Constituency Member) : Mr Speaker, just one supplementary question. Given that the Government has put forward this principle of self-reliance to Singaporeans, does the Minister feel that this situation, where a lot of elderly have to draw from their children's Medisave accounts, is a departure from this principle of self-reliance, because the children will also have to build up their own Medisave accounts for the future?

Mr Gan Kim Yong : Mr Speaker, I thank Mr Giam for the question. In fact, self-reliance is a very important underlying principle of our healthcare financing framework. But to ensure good health for Singaporeans, everyone has a role to play. Firstly, at the individual level, each one of us must take personal responsibility for our health. If we do not adopt healthy lifestyle, if we are not careful in our diet and eat laksa everyday and so on, I think no one can help us keep ourselves healthy. So, we have to take responsibility for our own state of health, and we also have to make it our personal responsibility to save up for rainy days, in case we fall ill one day.

Page: 444

But beyond the individual, family also plays an important role. Mutual support in the family will provide a second line of defence and this is part and parcel of our family values. This is what our society is about and it is important for us to continue to encourage mutual support within the family. We must not weaken that value.

And beyond the family, I think society, as a whole, also plays an important role. Just about three to four days ago, on Tuesday, I attended a concert called "Rays of Hope". The concert was organised by the National Cancer Centre of Singapore (NCCS). The concert was to raise funds for the young cancer patients. I think the society also plays a role. The doctors come together, raise funds for their patients. This is another very precious value of our society that we should try to preserve and, of course, the Government itself will also play its role. In fact, we spent about $2.2 billion a year providing subsidies for our patients.

So, I think this is part and parcel of our broader sense of self-reliance. At the individual level, we try to achieve sufficient savings for ourselves. Beyond the individual level, the family achieves self-reliance through mutual support. And beyond the family, society as a whole achieves self-reliance by helping one another. The Government, at a national level, achieves self-reliance by providing support for those who need it most.

Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song : Mr Speaker, I still remain concerned about the financial health of these children who have to fork out money for their parents' medical treatment. I understand this principle in our values that we have to support our parents, but for those children who are from lower income backgrounds – is there additional help that the Ministry intends to provide to them, to assist them as they assist their parents, so that they do not have to draw down on their meagre Medisave accounts to be able to help their parents.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : Mr Speaker, for the lower income, whether they are older or whether they are from the younger generation which Mr Giam was concerned about, the Ministry does help them for their medical needs. First and foremost, we want to encourage as many of them as possible to stay on MediShield, which should provide a basic insurance to cover most of the medical expenses in hospitals. We have provided up to 80% subsidy for our B2, C class wards in hospitals which generally have larger medical bills compared to outpatient.

With the Government subsidy for the B2, C class wards, generally, the patients would be able to afford the B2, C class bills without out-of-pocket expenses, only drawing from the Medisave, MediShield, and so on. Up to about 70% of them would have no out-of- pocket expenses. That means that they are fully covered, in one way or the other. Secondly, among those who have out-of-pocket expenses, the remaining 30%, about one-third of them, receives help from Medifund. So, we want to make sure that all Singaporeans whether you are in the high-income or low-income groups, whether you are old or young, will be able to receive medical treatment that is appropriate for them. We also provide financial counselling at the beginning to make sure that they opt for the right class of ward so that they can afford it. But, at the end of the day, I think it is important for us to emphasise individual responsibility so that we encourage them to save sufficiently for their old age for their medical needs and if they do get into trouble, we have many ways to help them.

Recently, I think the Prime Minister announced a series of initiatives to enhance our financial support for medical care, one of which is Primary Care Partnership Scheme (PCPS) which caters to the older and the lower-income Singaporeans to allow them to have subsidised care at the private General Practitioners (GPs). We have also enhanced the drugs subsidies at the hospitals and our polyclinics to ensure that the drugs will remain affordable to our lower income families.

Page: 445

Mr Cedric Foo Chee Keng (Pioneer) : Sir, it is heartening to hear from the Minister that there are many means to help the people who need healthcare in Singapore. And it is also heartening to hear that the Government will be there as a last resort, in the form of Medifund, if all else fails. Can I ask the Minister what percentage of applicants for Medifunds is rejected?

Mr Gan Kim Yong : I do not have the exact number on hand but I believe that most of the applicants who qualify would have been given the Medifund. Those who do not qualify, the hospitals will advise them. But even beyond Medifund, for those at the margins, we give a lot of flexibility to the individual institutions. Usually, there would be a Medifund Committee. These committees will evaluate application on a case-by-case basis. Even for patients up to middle-income, if they find that certain treatment or certain drugs are really beyond their reach, the hospitals have the flexibility to award them with Medifund support. And beyond Medifund, in fact, hospitals also have programmes to raise additional funding from philanthropists, from donors and from well-wishers. The example I gave just now – the NCCS concert programme – is an example of initiatives by the doctors who decided that they could do something to help these patients beyond Medifund and therefore they went ahead to raise funds. So, at the hospitals, at our institutions, there are many programmes. Some are funded by Medifund, some are funded by their own initiatives. Through all these programmes, we try to help our patients to ensure that they can afford the appropriate treatment.

Page: 445

Illegal Moneylending Activities

5 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs (a) whether the punitive, legal and enforcement measures to reduce illegal moneylending activities have obtained significant success; and (b) in view of the growing use of aggressive harassment techniques against innocent neighbours of recalcitrant debtors, whether the Ministry will consider making it an offence to borrow from loansharks to deter demand for these loans.

The Second Minister for Home Affairs (Mr S Iswaran) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs) : Sir, from January to September this year, there were 10,439 unlicensed moneylending and harassment reports. This is 24% lower than in the same period in 2010, that is, a reduction of about 3,200 cases. This reduction can be attributed to the punitive legal measures introduced in the Moneylenders Act last year, as well as the greater level of community vigilance, and effective Police enforcement. Over the same period, the number of persons arrested rose 24% to 1,492 persons.

The Member has asked about aggressive harassment tactics. The number of cases involving aggressive harassment tactics remains low, accounting for less than 0.5% of the total number of cases. The Police have apprehended the perpetrators in nearly 80% of these cases. In all such instances, the Police will press for stiff sentences against the perpetrators, including caning.

Page: 446

Mr de Souza's suggestion to make borrowing from loansharks an offence, as Members are well aware, has been raised and debated several times in this House. Opinion is divided on the matter, not least because the circumstances of each borrower are very different. It is not conclusive that criminalising borrowing will significantly diminish the loansharking situation, although it might deter some borrowers

Our current focus is on the plethora of other means to tackle the problem. The Police will continue with its stringent enforcement efforts and leverage on the enhanced legal measures. Police will also strengthen its partnership with the community and grassroots organisations to safeguard the neighbourhoods. Education is key in addressing the aspect of demand for unlicensed moneylending. In that regard, the Police will work with stakeholders like MCYS, the Registry of Moneylenders, and the National Council on Problem Gambling. Public education campaigns will highlight the alternative avenues of assistance and also warn those who may be inclined to work for loansharks of the serious consequences of doing so.

I would like to point out that the Ministry and the Police will closely monitor the effectiveness of these measures before assessing the need, if any, to go further. I want to assure the Member and this House that we are certainly prepared to introduce tougher measures if the situation warrants it.

Mr Christopher de Souza (Holland-Bukit Timah) : I would like to thank the Minister for his comprehensive reply and also the Home Team for their concerted effort in reducing the figures by 24%. Regulation on Easy Credit

6 Mr David Ong asked the Minister for Law (a) how many complaints against easy credit (moneylending) companies have been registered to date; and (b) whether the existing safeguards on interest rates for loan amounts above $3,000 or loans to persons with an income above $20,000 per annum, and penalties for late payments are sufficient to protect the man in street from chalking up insurmountable and often spiralling debts.

The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law (Ms Sim Ann) (for the Minister for Law) : Sir, since 2009, the Registry of Moneylenders has investigated a total of 105 complaints against licensed moneylenders. The Registry has also investigated many breaches that were discovered during regular and ad-hoc inspections and audits.

The Registry takes stern enforcement action against moneylenders who are found to breach the law. To date, seven moneylenders have had their licences suspended; six have had their licences revoked; and four have been prosecuted in court. Warnings have also been issued for minor breaches.

Mr Ong also asks if the existing safeguards are sufficient to protect a person from chalking up spiralling, insurmountable debts. Sir, for the benefit of the hon. Members, I will list some of the safeguards that have been legislated. But before that, please allow me to make a fundamental point. Some individuals do incur insurmountable debts with serious consequences for themselves and their families. This is a matter of concern to the Government. At the same time, there are limits to what the Government can do to protect everyone from getting into a financially difficult situation, or from getting himself or herself into debts that he or she cannot repay.

In the last two years, more than 2,000 persons became bankrupt, borrowing from banks and credit card companies. These companies do due diligence. Yet the borrowers get into financially distressed positions due to a variety of factors. The same goes for people who borrow from moneylenders. The solution is not to outlaw the moneylending industry or impose rules such that moneylenders cannot lend to people who need to borrow – by definition, they lend to people who need loans. If the Government controls the moneylending industry too much, people who can only borrow from moneylenders may resort to borrowing from loansharks.

What the Government can do, and has done, is set out a framework that can work for the majority, allows reasonable access to credit and tries to protect the borrowers within reasonable limits. How we should draw the framework depends on judgements we make on what will and will not work, and the way the market works in practice. We thus need to constantly review the rules and, where necessary, amend them, to make sure that they are working.

Page: 450

For instance, the purpose of relaxing the rules relating to advertising back in 2009 was to allow the consumer who needs credit, to more easily compare the terms between different moneylenders and choose the best one for his needs. However, having seen how licensed moneylenders have become aggressive in their marketing, we have now considerably tightened the rules on advertising, as we do not want advertising to drive demand for moneylenders.

This is not an end state. We are continuing to monitor and review what is happening. Where we see the market not functioning effectively, and if we believe that consumers can be better protected without cutting off access to credit, we will implement the necessary measures.

I will now set out some of the rules that protect borrowers. First, moneylenders are not allowed to charge borrowers who earn less than $20,000 a year, an interest rate of more than 18% per annum for unsecured loans of $3,000 and below. Second, moneylenders are not allowed to grant unsecured loans of more than $3,000 to such borrowers. Third, moneylenders are not allowed to grant unsecured loans exceeding two times the monthly income of borrowers who earn between $20,000 and $30,000 a year; or exceeding four times the monthly income of borrowers who earn between $30,000 and $120,000 a year.

Sir, I have set out what the Government can do. Ultimately, however, borrowers will have to exercise some judgement – they should assess whether they can repay the loan, and also not take up the loan if the terms and conditions are unreasonable.

Mr David Ong : Sir, I thank Ms Sim Ann for the reply. Given that many who come to these so-called licensed credit companies are in need of money and are desperate, they would probably agree to any term that is on the paper. Worse, they would borrow from multiple credit companies. If they take a loan of $5,000 from each company, and they could easily chalk up a $20,000 loan from four moneylenders. As the interest rates are not capped for those who are earning above $20,000 a year, I think we want to look at how to protect, not so much the borrowers, but the immediate innocent of these borrowers – their families, wives, children, parents and grandparents. I hope that the Ministry can look at an interest rate structure for those earning above $20,000 per annum because they will be exposed as they would agree to anything when they sign.

Ms Sim Ann : Sir, I thank Mr Ong for raising his suggestions and concerns. Indeed, we are monitoring the industry very closely as well as public feedback and we are reviewing the various aspects of how the industry is working. This includes, for instance, the example that he raised: borrowers going to multiple lenders. We will be reviewing how best to strike a balance between protecting the interest of borrowers and yet at the same time maintaining reasonable access to credit.

7 Mr Ang Wei Neng asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports in view of the doubling of new cases of preschoolers diagnosed with developmental problems from 2005 to 2010 (a) what is the number of such children being placed on early childhood intervention programmes for the past five years; (b) what is the current number of children on the waiting list and the average waiting time before such preschoolers can be placed on these programmes; and (c) what are the enrolment figures at Special Education (SPED) schools for this group of preschoolers in the past five years.

Page: 451

The Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (MG [NS] Chan Chun Sing) : Mr Speaker, Sir, MCYS shares Mr Ang Wei Neng's concern for the development of our young children, especially those with developmental challenges. Over the last five years, MCYS, the National Council of Social Service and the disability sector have worked together to provide more places in the Early Intervention Programme for Infants and Children (EIPIC). We have expanded capacity by 40%, growing from 1,350 places in 2006 to 1,900 today. The number of centres also increased from nine in 2006 to 14 today.

In recent years, there has been increasing awareness among parents on disability and developmental delays. At the same time, the MOH-Child Development Programme (CDP) has enhanced its capability and capacity on detection and diagnosis at a younger age. The number of pre-school children diagnosed with disability and developmental delays has almost doubled from about 1,300 in 2005 to 2,500 in 2010. Together, these factors have contributed to more children and younger children seeking intervention services.

For these reasons, there is still a shortage even though we have increased EIPIC places significantly. We now have about 500 children on the waitlist. The waiting time to enrol is on average six months. We recognise that it is important for the children to receive intervention services early, and are taking several steps to expand capacity urgently:

First, we are working with the Voluntary Welfare Organisations to open new EIPIC Centres. We have just opened a new centre last month with another new centre by April next year.

Second, we are working with existing EIPIC Centres to increasing their capacity by expanding their physical premises where possible, and increasing their manpower. To support them, my Ministry has introduced a new "Place-and-Train" scheme to allow centres to hire EIPIC teachers and therapists ahead of enrolment.

Third, MCYS and the Centre for Enabled Living have begun on a pilot this month to tap on selected private sector providers for EIPIC. We are starting with a small number of providers to evaluate the feasibility of tapping on the private sector for EIPIC in the longer term.

Sir, with these efforts, we will increase the number of EIPIC places by 700 more places by April next year. This should bring down the average time taken to enrol a child to three months. Incidentally, three months is also the period taken for the centre to work with the parents to assess a child's specific needs and discuss them with the parents before enrolment.

MG [NS] Chan Chun Sing : Mr Speaker, Sir, we thank Ms Denise Phua for her suggestions and we fully agree with her suggestions. The first issue raised was scalability. We are studying the models of other countries to see if there are other ideas that we can adopt that can allow the scaling up, without the intensive use of manpower resources.

At the same time, we are very cognisant that when dealing with children with special needs, inevitably we cannot be too efficient because there is a certain person-to-person interaction. Unlike a normal school where we can have a higher ratio of students to teachers, for many of these special needs places, we need a lot of management attention, a lot of teachers' attention. Extension of Dependants' Protection Scheme

8 Mr Patrick Tay Teck Guan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower whether the Dependants' Protection Scheme will be extended beyond the current age of 60 years which has remained unchanged since the scheme started in 1989.

The Minister of State for Manpower (BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the hon. Member of Parliament, Mr Patrick Tay for his question.

The Dependants' Protection Scheme (DPS) is an affordable term insurance scheme aimed at providing young dependants with a sum of money to tide over the initial difficult period in the event of an insured member's permanent incapacity or death. DPS is especially needed when a breadwinner has young children and when an untimely death could mean the loss of many years of future income. The need for DPS declines as a breadwinner nears his retirement age as he would have built up his own savings, and his children would probably have begun to fend for themselves. In the event of any untimely death, he would have his own savings (including CPF savings) which could support his remaining dependants.

Page: 454

Moreover, extending DPS beyond age 60 would also mean substantially higher premiums. It would be better to safeguard this money for their retirement needs instead of allowing the purchase of further cover. Setting the age limit at 60 is to balance the need for insurance protection for his dependants versus his own need for adequate retirement savings. Further, members who wish to purchase life insurance beyond the age of 60 can still do so from private insurers.

Therefore, my question to the Minister of State is whether, at this juncture, though he said that he is not reviewing it, his Ministry will consider reviewing it in the coming years.

BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin : Mr Speaker, Sir, this issue actually has been debated quite extensively in the last Parliament and the concerns raised are not dissimilar to what the hon. Member of Parliament has indicated. As I mentioned, the challenge is really balancing between the insurance needs as well as retirement needs. And importantly, there will be significant increase in premiums after the age of 60. Let me explain why. The premiums have been kept largely affordable. Between the ages of 25 and 60, the total premium paid by an individual for coverage would amount to about $4,000. After that age, premiums go up, and they would have to pay between $800-$900 each year, several times higher than their current premium of $260, which is for the age of 55 to 59. Therefore, the premiums would have gone up and the total premium for the coverage from age 60 to 65 alone would cost another $4,000. In that sense, we do feel that individuals may want to consider perhaps at that stage, where their children are a lot older, place more of the emphasis on retirement needs. However, on his question of whether the Ministry would consider, I think this is something that we are open to consideration. 9 Mr David Ong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower (a) what pace will the Ministry take to tighten the quota for foreign workers in Singapore; and (b) whether a more customised approach can be taken for SMEs, especially those in the food and beverage and food manufacturing industries which are facing more problems with the foreign worker quota, foreign worker levy and attracting Singaporeans to do the job.

BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower) : Mr Speaker, Sir, as part of our effort to prevent an increasing reliance on foreign manpower, especially low-skilled workers, we have been increasing the foreign worker levy (FWL) for Work Permit and "S" Pass holders progressively since July 2010. As announced previously, the levies will continue to be raised in six-monthly intervals up to July 2013.

Page: 455

We have not, in fact, tightened the foreign worker quotas. What we have done, however, is to tighten the entry criteria for the various work passes to raise standards and improve quality. The Government will periodically review the need for further adjustments, while providing lead time for companies to adjust. However, this is not all we are doing to encourage companies to restructure and to reduce their dependence on labour. The more important solution is for companies to invest in productivity, innovation and in upgrading the skills of their workforce. The Government is providing full support for these productivity and Continuing Education and Training (CET) efforts.

We recognise the difficulties many SMEs face in recruiting Singaporeans. The Government has introduced specific initiatives to help SMEs re-engineer their operations and to reduce their reliance on labour. One example is the SME Productivity Roadmap (SME-PRO), a joint initiative by the WDA and SPRING Singapore, which provides a systematic, three-step approach for SMEs to improve their productivity. A dedicated portal provides SMEs access to information and resources to help them take concrete actions to raise productivity. One feature of the portal is an online productivity calculator for businesses to work out their productivity levels and to benchmark against industry levels.

In addition, SMEs can avail themselves of the numerous sectoral-based productivity initiatives that the National Productivity and Continuing Education Council (NPCEC) has rolled out in 16 industries. SMEs that are cash-constrained and require more time to phase in their productivity investments also have the option of converting part of their Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) into a cash payout of up to $21,000 each year. This means that small companies with lower taxable income can enjoy up to $1,750 cash grant for every $10,000 spent on the qualifying activities under the PIC to boost productivity and innovation.

The Government will also continue to work closely with our tripartite partners to facilitate the employment of local residents. For example, we have a significant untapped pool of inactive residents, especially women, who could be encouraged to rejoin the workforce if the jobs offered flexibility. The Flexi-Works! scheme offers a grant of $100,000 to help companies implement part-time or flexible work arrangements. NTUC's Women Development Secretariat also hosts regular job fairs targeted at women who are new to the workforce or who have not worked for a long time and are considering rejoining the workforce. Another local pool of potential labour that companies can tap on is the older residents. The Retirement and Re-employment Act will take effect from 1 January 2012 to provide more job opportunities for older workers who do want to work. Through the ADVANTAGE! Scheme, we offer a financial grant of up to $400,000 to help companies recruit, retain and re-employ older workers. SMEs, including those in the food and beverage and food manufacturing industries, should actively tap onto these assistance schemes to improve their jobs and workplace conditions to attract local residents to join these industries.

Lastly, I would urge business and industry associations, such as the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) and the Singapore Manufacturers' Federation (SMa), to work closely with their members to leverage on these productivity schemes and to share the best practices because there are companies out there who are managing this transition. In fact, I just had very meaningful dialogues with both ASME and SMa over the past two months and I have found their feedback and suggestions very useful. We will continue to engage all our business associations and support their endeavours to help the smaller companies.

Casino-related Gambling Problems

10 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (a) whether the number of gamblers turning to the National Council on Problem Gambling for help as a result of casino-related gambling debts has risen between 2008 and 2011; (b) whether the Voluntary Welfare Organisations recorded an increase in the number of casino-related and problem gambling cases; and (c) what plans does the Ministry have to ensure that the ill-effects of gambling arising from casino addiction are stopped.

MG [NS] Chan Chun Sing : Mr Speaker, Sir, MCYS shares the concerns of many Members in this Chamber on the issues related to problem gambling. Problem gambling is a multi-faceted problem as studies have shown that problem gamblers participate in a range of gambling products. The gambling participation of problem gamblers is an issue that MCYS closely monitors.

We have previously conducted two gambling participation surveys in 2005 and 2008. The earlier studies indicated that both probable pathological and problem gambling rates among Singapore residents are between 1% and 2%. We are conducting our next survey, as we speak, and will share the findings when ready next year.

The opening of the casinos in 2010 has two possible effects. One, it creates new demand for casino gambling, and two, it substitutes previous demand for casino gambling. Even before the local casinos opened, demand for casino gambling existed as shown in our 2008 gambling participation survey where about one in 10 respondents reported participating in casino gambling overseas.

Although there is demand for casino gambling even before the local casinos opened, it is now easier for local gamblers to visit the casinos. Coupled with our public education efforts to encourage help-seeking, it is not surprising that more individuals and families are coming forward to seek help for gambling-related problems.

We see more individuals and families coming forward to seek help − this is the first step to recovery. There are counselling and treatment services at the Tanjong Pagar Family Service Centre and the National Addictions Management Service (NAMS) respectively. The total number of clients seen by these two agencies was 304 in 2008, and has been increasing. From January to August 2011, the number of cases seen was 568.

Page: 458

Individuals and families can also utilise casino exclusion measures. In terms of casino exclusions, as at 30 September 2011, there were 750 Family Exclusion Orders, 28,600 Third-Party Exclusions and 29,000 Self-Exclusions in force. The number of casino exclusion cases has also been increasing since the IRs opened.

The National Council on Problem Gambling (NCPG) has also engaged other legal gambling operators to implement exclusions. For example, individuals can already apply to exclude themselves from jackpot rooms in Singapore. These include those run by SAFRA and NTUC. They can also exclude themselves from the Telebet accounts of Singapore Pools and Singapore Turf Club. Families that have requested for casino exclusion for their family members are informed of these other exclusion options. There are, however, gambling forms such as 4D and Toto for which exclusion is difficult to enforce as the gambler can easily circumvent any exclusion by asking someone else to bet on his or her behalf.

Voluntary Self-Exclusion is available to both Singapore residents and foreigners. Employers of foreign workers can facilitate the applications for their workers to voluntarily exclude themselves from the local casinos. They can do so via the NCPG website or in hardcopy by hand or by registered mail.

Foreign workers may also apply for exclusion in person at the NCPG office or the Migrant Workers Centre. As at 30 September 2011, we have 22,700 Self-Exclusions by foreigners. This is encouraging but we can do more and NCPG will continue to monitor the take-up rate for exclusion by foreign workers.

NCPG will continue to strengthen gambling counselling and help services. The Council is currently looking into providing a wider suite of services in terms of integrated credit, legal and financial advisory services. The integrated services will better equip families to minimise the harm, especially financial harm, from heavy gambling as well as problem gambling.

My Ministry will continue to closely monitor to ensure the efficacy of existing social safeguards. We are prepared to strengthen the safeguards, if necessary, especially to protect the vulnerable groups in our society.

Mr Christopher de Souza : I like to thank the Minister for his comprehensive reply and for realising that there is indeed a lot of terrain to have to combat where gambling is concerned. My supplementary question is one to do with self-exclusion. I think self-exclusion requires a sense of discipline on the part of the person to say I do not want to gamble. Some addicts do not have that discipline. Neither do people who are attracted to the lure of gambling have or may not have that discipline. So rather than be over-reliant on self-exclusions, I would like to ask the Minister whether he would see how we can deter or reduce the lure of gambling, for example, advertisements put in the papers by the casinos of their latest gadgets or gambling machines. Alternatively, a reduction on their ability to advertise big wins. My supplementary question is based on discussions with NGOs who have disclosed to me their dealings with problem-gambling addicts and that the solution is really to reduce the lure of gambling.

Page: 459

MG [NS] Chan Chun Sing : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank Mr Christopher de Souza for his comments. Indeed, we agree with him that self-exclusion requires much discipline on the part of the individual. But we also know that not every individual will have the necessary self-discipline because if he has it in the first place, he may never get into trouble at all.

Beyond individual self-discipline, I think it is equally important for us and especially for those people that get into harm's way, to have the support of the family and the society, which is why for all the pathological gambling cases, all the problem gambling cases, it is so important for us to have the supportive framework that includes the closest family members, the society and friends. One of the ways where we can do this and improve upon this is that when we see somebody close to us who displays signs of being troubled by gambling-related issues, we should quickly highlight this and assist the person to get help as soon as possible before the problem becomes worse. And this is the same line of defence that we would like to have beyond the individual to the family to the society. All of us will need to play a part and work closely to prevent this problem from getting worse.

We also agree that we have to deter this lure of gambling and the glamour that seems to come with it, with misleading advertisements. Indeed, we have in place measures to make sure advertisements do not target our local population. I am sure we will all recall that not too long ago, there was an operator who targeted some of our people from the heartlands and we had taken decisive measures to stop this. With a recent change, any advertisements will come under MCYS to allow us to have a more direct influence over these. And we will not allow operators to misrepresent with advertising of those rare big wins to lure people in. All these are necessary measures and there will be many more of such issues that we must handle to educate our people on the dangers of gambling.

Indeed, from the feedback of the VWOs, in order to reduce gambling, we have to take a comprehensive approach that must include education from a young age to the dangers of gambling, to the wider issues of how we can help family members detect signs that their family members are getting into trouble, or even help to educate the rest of our population to look out for signs of problem gambling amongst friends and colleagues in the workplace. Prevention is better than cure. When we see something is not going right, we should all work together to try and provide help as much as we can before the person falls deeper into problem gambling.

We are concerned with this issue, with or without the casinos. As I shared with Members just a while ago, even before the advent of the casinos, we already had 1% to 2% who suffer from pathological or problem gambling. We are watching this very closely and we want to continue to ensure that we have a situation that we can manage, although we may never be able to eradicate gambling from society totally.

Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah) : Sir, two supplementary questions. Firstly, I would like to ask the Minister: for those 568 who sought help, what is the success rate? Debate on President's Address

(Fifth allotted day)

Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [17th October 2011],

'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:

"We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".'– [Dr Lam Pin Min]

Question again proposed.

The Minister for Education (Mr Heng Swee Keat) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I speak in support of the motion. In the last few days, Members have highlighted issues of concerns to Singaporeans: housing, healthcare, education, transport, the care of the elderly and the low-income, amongst others, and made many important suggestions on the way forward. I also thank the many MPs who spoke in support of MOE's focus on the student-centric values-driven education. I appreciate your many good suggestions which MOE will study together with other inputs. I was tempted to name every Member who had spoken but, at the last count, it was 20. I am encouraged by your support. I want to assure the hon. Minister for Finance that I will not ask for a bigger budget unless it is necessary. We will do what is best for the whole of Singapore.

Page: 461

In the last few months, I have met many parents, teachers and students. I have learnt a great deal, so please allow me to share some of this. I was encouraged to see students at our pre-university seminar so engaged in re-imaging Singapore, while those at the recent polytechnic forum freely shared their ideas, such as aspirations about the Singapore Dream. I have also met many different groups of students, including those in my constituency and at kopi chats. They asked me deep questions. How do we fulfil our aspirations? How can we contribute to Singapore? What kind of society will Singapore become? What is Singapore culture and what is the ideal Singaporean? I very heartened by their passion and thoughtful questions. As many Members have pointed out, the success of our education system is vital to Singapore's success. But the students' questions raised an even more fundamental point: they cannot fulfil their aspirations unless Singapore succeeds as a nation, and success has to go beyond the material to providing a deeper sense of fulfilment and well-being for all Singaporeans.

So, while this House has been and will continue to debate the specifics of many policies and programmes, the fundamental question remains: how can we best ensure the survival and success of Singapore, and improve the lives of Singaporeans? This is not a question that can ever be answered once and for all. It is a question we need to keep answering from one generation to another, from one government to another, from one year to another.

Yesterday, the Prime Minister highlighted the key challenges ahead and expressed deep confidence in our future if we continue to work towards an inclusive society, build a vibrant economy and have constructive politics. Listening to the Prime Minister, I think the best words to describe the style of government we seek is "citizen-centric government", which engages and works with citizens to improve the lives of all Singaporeans, based on values such as meritocracy, multi-racialism, hard work and self-reliance, creating opportunities for all to succeed. Economic growth, never the end goal, has enabled us to achieve holistic development as a nation − in our people and our social bonds, our defence and security, our environment and our heritage.

Taking a step back, the most critical challenge that the Prime Minister raised is for Singapore to embark on a new creative phase in our nation-building journey. This involves drive and vision, a spirit of innovation and imagination, a spirit of excellence and teamwork, a spirit of hard work and inclusion, so that we may continue to find and create new opportunities and make new breakthroughs in order to continue to improve the lives of Singaporeans. This also involves forging a new consensus about the core values and ideals that we subscribe to as a nation. We are a plural people. A modern, urban, multi-ethnic, multi-religious society on a small island. Our diversity can be a tremendous strength, but do we have a sense of unity as Singaporeans tied to a common destiny even though our views and our concerns, our doubts and our fears may be different? It is critical that we do.

Page: 462

Indeed, this question of shared values and ideals that the President referred to may be the more important enterprise in our nation building because if we do not get our domestic ship in order, there is little hope of our succeeding to navigate the challenges and opportunities of a volatile world.

The Prime Minister has spoken at length on the critical need for good government and to deepen the trust between the Government and our people. Implicit in what he said and what many Members of this House have said, is also the importance of getting three key relationships right: the relationship of self to others; the relationship of Singapore to the world; and, the relationship of the future to the past. We need to build a consensus about the values, ideas and ideals that underpin these relationships as they will frame our policies and national dialogues. Please allow me to elaborate.

Over the centuries, societies grappled with how to value the individual and how to value the collective. Some societies regard the individual as supreme and, indeed, some believe that societies exist to enable the individual to fully express himself. This allows diverse views and creative individuals to flourish. This respect for the individual underpins key social institutions, such as the rule of law, the rights to property, democracy and the market economy. Yet, an excessive focus on the individual – his rights, his needs, his wants, his aspirations, his achievements – will ultimately be detrimental both to the individual as well as to society. Such a person is self-absorbed and self-centred. He attributes his achievements to his own brilliance or diligence. As one cosmetic advertisement puts it "因为我值得", that is, "Because I deserve it" or "I'm worth it".

Such a cult of individualism also breeds an "us versus them" mentality, because while the successful in such a society may look at the weak or unsuccessful as "losers" who deserve their fate, the unsuccessful will resent and feel unfairly disadvantaged. This may give rise to a culture of envy, blame and a mentality of entitlement. A society of self-centred individuals is one which must, in the end, be highly stratified, fragmented, with a culture of cynicism and instant gratification. Such a Singapore would lose its exceptional quality of discipline and unity, which has, since Independence, allowed us as a nation to take difficult and tough choices in the near term in order to succeed and prevail over adversity in the longer term.

Matters are even more serious when we deal with groups. A close-minded focus on the uniqueness and rights of certain groups or causes will trigger and provoke deep divisive forces within a plural society. The risks of conflicts along lines of race, language or religion will never go away. As our society becomes more diverse, there may be new cleavages based on the advent of different interest groups, each holding different views, advocating for different causes, clamouring to advance their beliefs − often at the expense of others. The line which separates vibrant diversity and fractious fragmentation is a thin one.

We must therefore embrace both the individual and our collective. We must respect the individual and affirm the worth of each citizen in an inclusive way. Each of us is unique – in temperament, strengths and abilities. Singapore society must harness the unique strengths of each individual and protect the weak and vulnerable. Our values and ideals must include a commitment of the successful to help the less fortunate, to leave no man behind.

Page: 463

Let us recognise and enable bright and creative individuals to do their best works − the visionary leaders, entrepreneurs, inventors, scientists, thinkers, writers, artists, whose ideas lead to breakthroughs in society and which benefit us all. Let us also recognise the different aspirations, strengths and abilities of our people. As the Malay proverb goes, "Tukang tidak membuang kayu" or a craftsman never throws away any piece of wood. Just as every piece of wood has its character, everyone has his strengths and intrinsic worth. In our education system, we recognise the different potential and abilities of all our students, provide different pathways to allow each to go as far as possible. We celebrate their achievements, big or small, in different arenas.

I recently met students from our polytechnics and ITE who had just returned from the World Skills Competition in London. It is also known as the Olympics of Skills. I am very proud of their achievements. One student, Shunner Leong, won the Gold Medal in Beauty Therapy, while another student, Noel Ng, won the Medallion for Excellence in the Hairdressing category. Talking to them, I am deeply impressed by their knowledge, self-confidence and aspirations. And after days of intense debate in this House, if Members feel that you need a good haircut or a beauty therapy, I highly recommend them to you.

We must have good schools in every neighbourhood. For children with special needs, let us help them to achieve their best and to lead meaningful lives, as Ms Denise Phua and Ms Low Yen Ling so passionately argued for.

Beyond recognising individual differences and strengths, we must find practical ways to make our diversity positive and productive. A good school is one that develops each child according to his strengths. A good organisation, as Peter Drucker noted, makes individual strengths productive and weaknesses redundant. A good society harnesses the diverse strengths of each individual to enable each to be more than he can ever be alone and, at the same time, protects the weak and vulnerable. How do we achieve this?

First, let us celebrate teamwork. While heroic acts of individuals capture our imagination, it takes a team to accomplish anything significant. Steve Jobs could not have brought the iPhone or iPad to the market without the collective efforts of designers, engineers, technicians and many others who toiled behind the scenes. No football team has ever won by fielding only one super player.

I believe Singapore will continue to throw up unique and outstanding individuals who will make a disproportionate impact on the world stage. But Singapore goes beyond individuals. We are well-positioned as an innovative nation because we can harness the power of large-scale innovation that requires collaboration and teamwork and a drawing together of sophisticated systems. Yesterday, the Prime Minister spoke about the premium that comes with an excellence at a systems level.

Second, we must enlarge and deepen our common space, and have a unifying purpose based on shared ideals and values. Diversity is a strength only when our common space is not only large but also growing, and when it is based not only on shared experiences and daily interaction, but also on shared purpose, ideals and values as well as inter-personal and trusted bonds woven through mutual respect and consideration between individuals, groups and communities.

Page: 464

Third, let us cheer and spur each other on. We must celebrate success not just of ourselves and our own children's, but also those of fellow Singaporeans and their children. We must not begrudge those who have worked hard and done well, or seek to cut them down like tall poppies. Instead, we should find avenues for our children and ourselves to be the best that we can be and, at the same time, encourage and recognise others when they in turn try to be the best that they can be. As Confucius said, "己欲立而立人，己欲达而达人", that is, "The benevolent man establishes for others, achievements he wishes for himself. He brings others to reach goals which he wishes to achieve for himself."

Fourth, those who are successful should not forget what they owe their success to and give back to the broader society. Let us promote a spirit of giving and make volunteerism, philanthropy, corporate social responsibility and social enterprises a way of life, a part of the Singaporean DNA. For in giving, we receive.

I thank the many individuals and foundations who have so generously donated to our schools, institutions of higher learning, and the thousands of professionals who served on their boards, councils and school advisory committees. Tens of thousands of parents are serving in our parent support groups. Their efforts will help us make every school a good school. Many others serve as community and grassroots volunteers, in various special schools, volunteer welfare organisations and other charitable causes. Many Singaporeans donate generously to Community Chest and other causes.

They have a sense of joint stewardship for Singapore society. The success of Singapore and the character of our society depend not just on the Government, but on every Singaporean. This is why MOE seeks not just to develop each child to his or her full potential, but also to prepare the active citizen, concerned about the public good and for others in society.

Fifth, as Mdm Halimah Yacob reminded us yesterday about the pitfalls, we must not treat those we help as helpless beneficiaries, but to look to what they can contribute. We must not diminish their sense of worth and dignity. A few days ago, I was delighted to present a certificate of service to a 72-year-old lady who was serving those more elderly than her at the Kampong Senang Home. One of my Tampines residents in his 50s, struggling to bring up his grandchild as his daughter had just lost her husband, declined any help despite my persistence. I was glad that he eventually accepted a bursary for his other child for his study because the child had done well. These Singaporeans remind me of the moving image of the Japanese quake victim who apologised to her rescuers for the inconvenience she caused. I admire their sense of personal responsibility and ruggedness, which we must cultivate even as we grow a society that aspires to leave no one behind. A caring society and rugged individuals must go hand-in-hand.

Finally, let us temper our competitive instincts with an abundance mentality. There are some goods which are "exclusive" – if I have it, you cannot have it. Yet there are many others where my enjoyment not only does not deprive you of it, but actually enhances yours. A telephone system is valuable when many more people have access to it. There are many areas where we can all enjoy more – good books, music, knowledge, nature. Civic virtues, like keeping our streets clean, raise the standard for all.

The more gracious, kind and giving our society is, the greater our sense of joy and well-being. There is something in the spirit of man which derives its greatest pleasure by contributing to the lives of others. Indeed, this is what makes teachers so special – the further in life their students get to, the greater is the evidence of their own success and their sense of joy!

Page: 465

In short, let us open our hearts – to respect and appreciate everyone, to strive and cooperate with others, to celebrate our collective achievements, to create new opportunities for the future, and to cultivate new sources of fulfilment in life. Let Singaporeans be known to be a people with an abundance mentality – an abundance of helping others succeed, an abundance of kindness and giving, and an abundance of gratitude. In this way, we can value the individual, affirm his worth, as well as value the collective and build a cohesive society.

The second set of relationships is between Singapore and the world. We need to value the global, and value what is ours, what is local.

Lord Palmerston, English statesman of the 19th century, once said, "Nations have no permanent friends or allies, they only have permanent interests." It would do us well to take this to heart and understand that independence and success for Singapore lies in being uniquely relevant to the world. Our existence as a country and a people must be beneficial to the world.

We must stay open in learning from others but, equally, we must be bold to be different and unique where that would be right for Singapore. We must think through issues thoroughly, and not just copy and say, "why wouldn't we be like country X", or "let's do what country Y is doing". Certainly, we must be humble to learn, but, surely, Singaporeans must be the ones who understand Singapore's context, constraints, vulnerabilities, capacities, capabilities and opportunities best.

What will make us distinctive? In essence, it is about building on and turning whatever we have into strengths.

In earlier years, we promoted tolerance and understanding in our multi-racial, multi-religious, multi-cultural society. We have important safeguards against extremist elements. Today, few nations have achieved our level of racial and religious harmony. Let us continue to harness this heritage, so that our children can connect comfortably with every race and culture in the world. Let our Inter-faith Dialogue be a model, let us be a voice of reason and responsibility. Let us strive to be a nation where diverse people and good ideas can flourish, because we are not torn by deep vested interests or sectarian conflicts.

Because we are small, we naturally look outwards, learning from and appreciating the best the world has to offer – whether it is in cuisine, music, the arts or the sciences. We access the great ideas of science and the great works of art that speak to the human condition, across time and space. It connects us with people of the world, past and present. By encouraging our children to learn their mother tongue and other languages, they acquire another window to access their cultural heritage of the past and the cultural offerings of the world.

Building on this, let us celebrate and promote our local cuisines, our local arts, music and literature; give opportunities to our budding writers and artists to capture the idiosyncrasies and flavours of Singapore. I would love to see our teachers and writers creating stories for our students, stories that they can instinctively resonate with. I applaud what the NAC would be doing to develop our arts.

Page: 466

Let us encourage our companies, to transcend the constraints of our small markets, by innovating. The old adage that necessity is the mother of invention is best illustrated in our water constraints. Our water problem has stimulated innovative companies. Our architects are well placed to design for compact living, our engineers well positioned to provide green urban solutions. Let us make Singapore a city that works, so that it may be a crucible for innovation.

And small though Singapore is, let us value and preserve our natural heritage – our Bukit Timah Nature Reserve has more species of trees than even the whole of North America, unbelievable that may sound. I am glad our Bukit Timah Nature Reserve is now part of the ASEAN Heritage.

By embracing our local heritage and by staying open to what the world can offer, we can deepen Singaporean's sense of identity and self-confidence. It allows us to be a Singaporean rooted in our country, yet global in outlook, equipped to reap opportunities in the world. It makes us different and distinctive.

The third set of relationships is with respect to time. To live well in the present, we need to know the past and have a sense of the future.

There is an ancient saying by the famous poet Avaiyaar,"தொன்மை மறவேல்" "thonmai maravel". I hope Vikram will approve of my pronunciation. The literal meaning is "Do not forget the past". We should value the past, treasure our culture, and have a sense of where we come from.

Our fortunes and our history are inextricably intertwined with those of our neighbours and our world. The likely shift of the economic centre of gravity towards Asia will bring about new changes, and our young must understand our past to appreciate the broader forces at work.

In the 1840s, when Singapore was thriving as a port, pundits predicted, including our own business leaders, our decline when Hong Kong was ceded to the British. In the 1960s, critics called the Jurong Industrial Estate "Goh's Folly". Yet, we have defied the odds.

I opened the MOE Heritage Centre in September. It traces the history of our education system over the years. It was touching for me to see how, in the past, despite the meagre resources, clans, missionaries, and local Malay and Indian communities did their best to support parents and educators to give the children a good education. It was instructive to see how our education system evolved as our economic and social circumstances changed. One teacher told me she could not believe we raised the achievements in Mathematics for our students within a few short years, once we all put our minds to it. Many teachers came away feeling very inspired.

A sense of history gives us not only the perspective of how we got here but also the confidence to forge ahead. I applaud MICA for embarking on a collective memory project to celebrate our 50th Anniversary of Independence, and MICA and MND for preserving and conserving our heritage sites. These are critical, for emotional bonds among our people come from shared memories, especially memories of happiness, of crises and of triumphs. We should do more to understand our history and honour our pioneers and our earlier generation, as Mr Seng Han Thong and many others reminded us.

Page: 467

At the same time, we must seek to leave a legacy for our children. We must leave enough resources for them, and the best gift we can give them is a good education. As a small nation, we have to make our way in the world as it is, not what we wish it to be. Globalisation, technological advancements, changing demographics and shifting expectations will profoundly transform the world around us. We can expect new challenges but also new opportunities.

The future belongs to the nations that can stay ahead and respond effectively to the rapidly changing environment, and are ready for the future. This demands deep thinking and sound long-term policies. So even as we work through immediate issues, let us not lose sight of the future.

Let us build our capacity, as a society, for long-term planning, for the sake of future generations. It is not good enough that we have survived and succeeded up to now.

Survival and success are inextricably intertwined in the case of Singapore. We have to keep working the ingredients and adjust the formulas that will assure survival and success for the coming generations.

I am optimistic that we will succeed in our next creative phase of nation building, with a citizen-centric Government, driven by shared values, committed to working with citizens to improve the lives of all Singaporeans. At the same time, Singapore's success in the next phase also depends on the character of our society and what citizens do to uphold the public good. I believe Singapore will succeed if we have both good Government and exceptional Singaporeans.

Singaporeans with the determination and creative impulses to succeed, a sense of responsibility and appreciation for others, a mentality of abundance; Singaporeans with a strong identity, rooted in Singapore, yet global in outlook; Singaporeans with a sense of their own history, and a sense of confidence and optimism about the future.

I call on Singaporeans to continue to boldly open our hearts, and expand our vision; and to embrace seemingly contradictory values in framing these three key relationships.

When we have the trust between our Government and our people, and the right relationships between self and others; our nation and the world; our past and our future, we will have an inclusive and supportive society, an enterprising and creative people, and a resolute and resilient nation. We will have created the conditions for all Singaporeans to continue to pursue their dreams and aspirations.
