Ms Tin Pei Ling (Marine Parade) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion of thanks to our President.

Page: 468

Last Monday, the President spoke of the need to build an inclusive nation that all of us can be proud of. He spoke of what Singapore had achieved, and urged the nation to unite to build our future in a new environment.

Indeed, Singapore has done well. In the 46 years since our Independence, Singapore has achieved tremendous economic success. We did not grow our economy for its own sake, but to let our people improve lives, and aspire beyond bread and butter.

I remember in 2009, when we were hit by the recession, I could sense deep anxiety and uncertainty all around. Many of us were worried about jobs. Some of my friends were even advised to take long, unpaid leave so as to keep their jobs for as long as possible. Stories of other Singaporeans being retrenched or counselled out were unsettling and all that we could do was to keep our heads down and worked hard. Then within a short span of time, in 2010, our economy was on the up again. All of a sudden, friends around me started to talk about looking for new jobs that promised to be even more exciting. Dreams and aspirations slowly crept back into the conversations.

What this showed me was that our economy must remain strong so that we can continue to bring bread back to the table. It also showed me that once we achieved that, we can then have the capacity to think and act on achieving the higher order things in life.

So far, Singapore has done well in ensuring that our economics and politics are right, and we should continue to do so. But as we continue to strive for growth, I am confident that we have the capacity to do more to help those in need. As the Prime Minister had set out in his speech yesterday, one of our key objectives should be to strive for a society in which no one is left behind.

Our system gives everyone opportunities to rise according to his or her own talents. But it is not enough to create opportunities for those who are able. We must also help those who are vulnerable. Singapore must be judged not just by the heights achieved by the most capable amongst us, but also by how high our society is able to lift those who need more help.

This goal will require all Singaporeans to work together. The Government does not have the sole responsibility to do so but it has a large responsibility − to help and uplift the destitute, the elderly, the disabled and the less fortunate. There is much that has to be done, but today my speech will focus on helping our elderly.

I pay particular attention to elderly issues, because one in three residents in MacPherson is aged 50 years old and above. But our entire nation is also ageing.

When Singapore first gained Independence in 1965, we were a young nation. The earliest reported median age of our population was 20 years old in 1970. Today, this median age has almost doubled to about 38 years old. Our population age pyramid is therefore inverting and we need to embrace this reality that more needs to be done to take care of older Singaporeans.

The older generation of Singaporeans made Singapore what it is today. We have a moral responsibility to take care of them, to help them enjoy fulfilling lives in their silver years. We will all grow old, some sooner than others. This is a harsh reality of life, but we can make it less harsh.

Page: 469

Therefore, I will speak on two key issues pertaining to older Singaporeans, the first being healthcare.

We have a comprehensive healthcare system, but healthcare remains a major concern for many Singaporeans. The elderly, in particular, deserve more help because they face particular challenges.

First, we need more health and medical care as we age, and seniors take a longer time to recuperate. Studies have also shown that seniors above the age of 65 years are about two to three times more likely to require healthcare.

Second, the elderly tend to have low income or no income. To save money, some may postpone or forgo sorely-needed medical treatment. Worse, with shrinking families, elderly parents with chronic illnesses have fewer children to help shoulder the burden.

Just recently, I met an elderly couple during a block visit. The husband suffers from renal impairment, hyperlipidaemia and mild dementia. He could hardly get off his bed. The wife suffers from diabetes and white blood cell disorder. However, both of them are not receiving or visiting the doctors to receive the medical attention that they need because they are worried about high medical fees. This is despite the subsidies, and despite their Medisave, which is actually depleting. Their only child, a son, is a low-income worker, and is unable to contribute much. Shockingly, the elderly lady even said that she is prepared to let her husband die. I am now working to get them help from Medifund.

This case shows that healthcare costs can weigh heavily on many elderly. This may even deter them from seeking treatment early, increasing the risk of complications that may cost them more later and, worse, endanger their lives. Some elderly may also not fully understand the range of different schemes available to help them. Many cannot tell the difference between Medisave, MediShield and Medifund. Sometimes, on probing an elderly Singaporean's healthcare difficulties further do we then realise that they could have benefited from MediShield and Medifund much earlier.

I applaud the enhanced subsidy schemes and MOH's recent pledge to improve financing policies to help needy patients. This will no doubt ease the mind of more elderly Singaporeans. But we should continue to monitor and review such schemes to meet the changing needs of our population and make available new essential treatments. We should also strengthen the communications of available help schemes to our elderly Singaporeans. For instance, financial counselling and advisory on payment options and financial assistance schemes should be offered to elderly patients upfront, without them having to ask, so that they, or their caregivers, could make a more informed decision.

We now have improved financing policies, but still, we hear cries for more support and I think we can do more. Specifically, just like how Singapore citizen children in Government primary schools need not pay for primary school fees (miscellaneous fees not included), might this House also consider taking the bold step of providing free basic healthcare to elderly Singaporeans in public healthcare settings?

Page: 470

In a time where the term "new normal" is abuzz, perhaps it is also time to re-consider the type of social compact we want for this era. I fully appreciate that we should uphold the principle of self-reliance and the value of family support. They remain cornerstones of our society. But just as importantly, our society has a duty to take care of those who have done so much for Singapore. The question to ask ourselves then is: How much is this generation of young Singaporeans willing to give of ourselves, to support the older generation, especially those who came from the founding generation of Singapore citizens?

The President highlighted that we want a fair and just society that ensures the well-being of every citizen. Therefore, we must be fair to those who have contributed and be just in caring for those who need more help, or have less access to resources. Perhaps, this is an area that should be considered. And if it would be considered, calibration of details can be explored further.

Mr Speaker, I will now speak in Mandarin on another issue concerning older Singaporeans.

(In Mandarin): [Please refer to Pg 527 for Vernacular Speeches.] Many older Singaporeans, especially those who have not reached their retirement age, hope to continue to have a stable job. Among them, some may enjoy working and want to keep active; some have no choice but to press on as they need to survive and support their families. Regardless of the reason, it is important that we must ensure ample and fair employment opportunities for older Singaporeans who wish to work.

Unfortunately, many older Singaporeans face a greater challenge than others when looking for a job. According to a report released by the Ministry of Manpower and Department of Statistics, the median unemployment period for an older Singaporean was 12 weeks, four weeks longer than the median unemployment period for all citizens. Many of these older Singaporeans who wish to work but cannot find a job for a long time become what is known as "discouraged" workers. They believed a job hunt is futile.

A few months ago, I came across one such "discouraged" worker. He is a MacPherson resident in his late 50s and was not English-educated. I had seen him around MacPherson a couple of times, and one day went up to chat with him. Through our conversations, I found out that he used to work as a driver, but had been unemployed for a while. Despite that, he would still put on his work clothes every morning, leave the house and then roam around. Why is this so? Because he did not want his wife to know that he was unemployed and worry about him. He also told me that he had been applying and going for job interviews, but to no avail. There were instances when he almost clinched a job, but then he had to declare his age, and afterwards, he would be greeted with "We'll call you back". They never called him back.

He is still looking for a job and we are trying to help him through the CDC. Still, it is tough-going and more needs to be done.

I believe his case is not unique in Singapore. If we want to build an inclusive society, where all Singaporeans can progress together, then we need to do more to help people like this resident of mine. Such efforts cannot be solely dependent on older job-seekers. Employers and the Government must give their strong support too.

Page: 471

Older workers have to upgrade themselves to become employable. Sometimes they have to retrain for a completely different type of work. The Government has introduced various programmes to encourage workers to upskill and retrain. This is heartening and I support these initiatives. But I would urge the administrators of such job programmes to be more patient with older workers, who may need more time to complete. It is not easy for someone who had been working 30 years in one field to switch to a completely different one. For those who never had an English education, this can become even more challenging. They need to be gently counselled to become willing to make the transition, and gradually guided to gain confidence to take on new and different jobs.

Employers and the Government should work more closely together too. For practical reasons, the Government has tightened up the control over foreign workers. Hence, older workers will become a precious human resource. Employers should therefore change their mindset and attitude and see these workers as human assets with rich life experiences.

The Government had also rolled out programmes to encourage employers to hire older Singaporeans. For instance, the Advantage! Fund is a financial scheme offered to companies to redesign jobs and adapt working environment in better enabling older Singaporean workers to do their work and achieve their potentials. Hence, I hope that the Government will continue to encourage employers to make the necessary adjustments through a comprehensive policy framework.

I believe through the collaborative efforts of the tripartite partners, we can help the older Singaporeans who wish to work to have a steady job and income. They should not need to worry about the future.

(In English): From older Singaporeans, let me now turn to young Singaporeans. In his Address, the President spoke extensively about engaging the young. He urged the young "to work with citizens, young and old, to improve on what you have inherited, and keep on transforming our nation for the better".

Indeed the young are doing so in many different ways. In MacPherson, young people have come up with initiatives to make the district a cleaner, greener place, to help the less fortunate by giving their homes a fresh coat of paint, to cultivate the arts by coming up with Singapore's very first community art gallery, to save stray cats and even to push for plans for the rejuvenation of the entire estate. I am sure that all over Singapore, there are youths similarly involved in such ventures.

We need to empower and challenge our youths more. We need to create opportunities and provide resources for young Singaporeans to hone our skills, gain precious experience and contribute positively and tangibly to our society. We should engage youths beyond forums and dialogues, instead to take it further and involve young people to co-create and achieve our vision of Singapore.

Some have expressed concerns that young people do not know the lessons of our history and the realities of life. They say that we have romantic notions of what Singapore can become, and risk losing the qualities that have led to our success.

Page: 472

There is no need to worry. MOE's National Education lessons have been successful. We may not have experienced the actual historical events but we understand that our forefathers had made many sacrifices to bring Singapore to where it is today. We know the challenges of our geopolitical circumstances and we do not forget the lessons of our history.

But we also sincerely believe that Singapore can be better. We believe that Singapore can be a fairer place, where individuals can aspire to do their best regardless of their family background. That Singapore can offer more opportunities, especially for those who do not take the straight and narrow road, but who have different talents in a multiplicity of fields. That Singapore can be more inclusive, so that all can share in the benefits of our development.

Hence, while young people know that earlier generations have done a lot of good for Singapore, we also want to be able to forge our own path ahead. There is a ferment in our society. Young people are supporting different causes and expressing diverse views on a range of issues.

The Government and society need not over-react to the loud and sometimes strident debate, especially on the Internet. Sure, there should be guiding principles and even a code of conduct. But robust debate or even disagreement on issues shows that young Singaporeans are genuinely concerned about the future of Singapore − our Singapore.

We should let things take their natural course. Young people will gradually figure out for ourselves the way forward, by trying out new ideas and working out which sacred cows can be slayed, and ultimately pushing out the boundaries of what Singapore can achieve.

Our Government and society should continue to invest in education, to prepare the next generation for the world of tomorrow. They should also emphasise values, for values will anchor us as a society even as global tides of change sweep past us. They should also build strong institutions, to help sustain the qualities that had enabled our nation to succeed.

But then the Government and society must also have the confidence that young people will rise to the challenge; to make mistakes but pick ourselves up, to be good stewards of Singapore, not to leave it the same, but to mould it according to our beliefs, and take our nation to new heights of excellence. With that, Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion.

Mr Low Thia Khiang (In Mandarin): [Please refer to Pg 528-529 for Vernacular Speeches.] Mr Speaker, Sir, the President concluded his Address at the Opening of the Twelfth Parliament with an emphasis on maintaining Singapore's uniqueness. I think, besides what was mentioned in the President's Address, the uniqueness should also include our cultural and linguistic diversity. Singapore has all along been a multi-racial society ever since Independence. The different languages and cultures have made our cultural scene very colourful.

However, with the standardisation of the education system and the teaching media, the languages and cultures of all the three ethnic groups are affected to some degree. There are major changes in the use of Chinese. Starting from the 1960s, various policies implemented within just one generation have led to the extinction of dialects in the Chinese society. Replacing the dialects is Mandarin. Now, the trend is going towards "keep English, abandon Chinese". We see the percentage of Chinese students speaking English at home surpassed that of Chinese students speaking Mandarin at home. This seems to have become an irreversible trend.

Page: 473

Currently, the Chinese language in Singapore is at a key transformational stage. With the rise of China and the change of external environment, we feel more and more strongly the importance of the Chinese language. Although we have implemented the bilingual policy for many years, young people educated under this system are generally not outstanding in their bilingual performance. Perhaps, these so-called bilingual, bicultural young people can communicate in Chinese on a daily basis. In terms of speaking, they have reached the upper middle level. However, they have lost the ability to read and write; many of them cannot read Chinese newspapers or literary material.

In addition, the rise of the Chinese Internet will create more challenges for these young bilingual people. Indeed, what Ms Sim Ann said is true. The Chinese language has a strong vitality and it will not be rendered redundant by the Internet and computerised input. The Chinese language has become more "lively" in this platform. A good example is the birth of "hot" Internet words, such as "the Rich 2nd generation 富二代(fu er dai)" and "the Official 2nd generation 官二代(guan er dai)". Mixed together with words from real life, they draw a vivid picture of the society.

Many young Singaporeans created high-quality English websites, discussing politics, society, economics, culture and other topics, but how many of them enter the Chinese Internet world? We can understand and speak Chinese, but if we cannot read and write, are we not becoming the illiterate in the global Chinese Internet world? In addition, among the participants of those seemingly hot cultural activities, language competitions and Chinese cultural courses run by schools and universities, how many are Singaporeans?

We always say that being bilingual gives us an advantage in the global competition. If we look at it honestly, we see that our Chinese language has become an oral language. Then how likely can we win this competition? Currently, are we just living on our past gains?

To reverse the "English first, Mother Tongue second" trend is already not possible. What we can do at least is to deepen and widen the Mother tongue learning experience.

We always emphasise how successful bilingual education has brought us competitive advantages and bilingual education seems to become an important Singapore brand. Why then, after English became the dominant and the first language of Singapore, the standard of our students' Mother Tongue started to languish? What is more puzzling is that our bilingual education system can do nothing but go into a retreat mode.

In this situation, I think we should adjust the emphasis of our bilingual policy. In other words, it is time to shift the emphasis on English to Mother Tongue. Otherwise, once Mother Tongue education disintegrates, our bilingual policy will only exist in name.

Page: 474

I hope, when it comes to the weightage of Mother Tongue and the implementation of Chinese education reform, MOE can also pay attention to cultural heritage, besides pedagogy and using new interactive media. While emphasising the daily functionality of the language, we should also cultivate the understanding and appreciation of the culture.

The language policy of this little red dot will not impact the world's language landscape, be it Chinese, Indian or Malay. However, our language policy, especially Chinese, will definitely affect our next generation's global competitiveness. In the near future, in the Chinese-speaking world including China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, more and more youth will master both English and Chinese. Even in the West, the number of youth learning Chinese is increasing every year. Youth in these countries will have the best of the East and West in terms of culture and information, because they are bilingual or even multilingual. They can roam free in the real and virtual worlds, East and West. By then, our youth will not only lose the advantage they had, but also will be in an inferior position. I think a government that cares about its people should worry about this. We should also think about this when discussing the future direction of policies.

(In English): Sir, in his Address, the President stated that our shared goal is to create a better life for all. Sir, we share this goal. We also agree that economic growth is basic to improving our lives. I do not think anyone of us here expects money to drop from the sky. Singaporeans are pragmatic and mature enough to understand this.

Besides normal economic indicators, we should consider other indicators reflecting the happiness and well-being of a society, as articulated in the United Nations resolution initiated by Bhutan and supported by Singapore. In Bhutan's case, they use Gross National Happiness (GNH).

The President described the situation after the General Election as a "new normal". Should the Government not view indicators, such as GNH, as a "new normal", in addition to GDP and GNP? I hope that this is not a sign that the Government's memory of the people's reactions to its policies during the General Election is fading.

In the President's Address, a promise was made to our senior citizens that "you can spend your silver years with peace of mind" – a promise which I take to heart. Yes, this is what our senior citizens deserve. It is only fair that those who have contributed to the progress of the nation, who have moved Singapore from the Third World to the First World, should be recognised and treated accordingly. This is what a responsive and responsible government should do.

To ensure that our senior citizens will live with peace of mind and dignity, the Government must provide affordable healthcare and adequate housing as well as appropriate retirement financing. This will require more Government expenditure.

When MPs from the Workers' Party raised questions related to these issues in this House, they were met with criticisms from the PAP. We were often warned about the dangers of a "welfare state". We were reminded that there is always a trade-off in any policy. This makes me wonder whether the promise to our senior citizens in the President's Address will remain as a promise worth less than the paper on which it is given – until the next general election.

Page: 475

While I agree that we should be mindful of the pitfalls of a welfare state, I think it is high time that the PAP MPs refrained from using this as a "red herring" to kill debate on alternative solutions and mechanisms to those proposed by the Government.

In this regard, I was glad to hear the Prime Minister yesterday make the commitment to strengthen our social safety nets in healthcare, housing and CPF. I hope our senior citizens will see the Prime Minister fulfil his pledges to make a real difference to their lives.

Sir, indeed, we should be fully aware of potential trade-offs in policy. We should also be on guard against viewing trade-offs only from the Government's perspective. We should always assess trade-offs from the people's perspective, especially those who are severely affected by the policy. However, the Government has often used €˜trade-offs' as and when it suited them.

When the Government allowed two casinos to be built here, it highlighted the benefits to our economy over related gaming and social ills – never mind the trade-offs. When the Government decided to go ahead with hospitalisation means testing without a transparent safety net for the sandwiched "not too poor, not too rich" group, it spoke about subsidising those who needed it most.

To shorten the long queue for subsidised rental flats, the Government's expedient solution was to disqualify more people from applying. They were told to live with their children, regardless of how that could affect family relationships and, as a result, some elderly people suffer emotionally. The Prime Minister acknowledged yesterday that the issue of higher demand for subsidised rental housing was not straightforward, but it needed attention.

However, Sir, the general feeling among Singaporeans during the General Elections and even now is that the Government is more concerned with paying its Ministers well than about the welfare of the people. I think that the Government must ask itself why Singaporeans feel and think this way.

I believe, Sir, the answer lies in the policy "trade-offs" expounded by a Member on the Government bench. It seems to me that more often than not, the policy trade-off was biased against the people, especially those who are adversely affected.

The policy "trade-off" is nothing more than a political assessment by the Government. The assessment is whether people can withstand it – or as we say in Malay, "boleh tahan" – the impact of the policy. But when the people "tak boleh tahan", the Government will "kena" and get hit during the election. This is what happened during the recent election in May.

The Government should also thank the Opposition parties for making tremendous efforts despite the lack of resources to allow Singaporeans to exercise their right to vote and express their views. The Opposition parties have also enabled the Government to awaken to the problems on the ground that it had thought were manageable.

Page: 476

I am happy to note that the PAP has done some reflection on the ground reactions and the Government has responded to some of the concerns of the people.

We have seen a spectrum of policy changes since the election in May even before the opening of Parliament. I am also happy to note the shift in the focus of our education philosophy. In this regard, the announcement in this House that the MCYS is now not only looking after the "in risk group", but will also be focusing on "at risk group" is a positive step. Here we are, in this House, the Twelfth Parliament, which we hope is the beginning of a "First World Parliament" befitting a First World nation, Singapore.

While the lack of resources and information may hamper the Workers' Party from developing alternative policies, it will not deter us from doing our best to contribute to the debate in Parliament on behalf of our electorate and the people of Singapore. We will scrutinise policies for any loopholes or gaps that are likely to affect our people adversely. We will be the voice of the people in the House so that the Government will always consider their concerns and needs in any policy trade-off.

I urge the PAP to step out of the shadow of the doom and gloom of certain pitfalls of western liberal democracy and work towards a First World Parliament in our own way, the Singapore way, to build a better life for all Singaporeans and a prosperous Singapore, based on justice, equality and happiness for our people.

Dr Intan Azura Mokhtar (Ang Mo Kio) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I join the other Members of the House in thanking the President for his Address at the Opening of this Twelfth Parliament.

Being the last of the new MPs to speak, I find that there are not that many new issues to talk about. After the Minister for Education, Mr Heng Swee Keat, talked about education, I thought, "Well, there goes half of my speech", and after fellow parliamentarian Ms Tin Pei Ling talked about youth, I thought, "There goes the other half." I do not think I would be able to deliver anything earth-shattering or that would have profound impact on our economy or the GDP. I do not proclaim to be a patriot or leader to speak on behalf of the people. Neither do I call for new legislation. But I wish to speak based on my personal experience and observations, and I hope that I am speaking not just from what is up here [points to her head] but from what is in here [points to her heart].

Our society has achieved commendably on many fronts. We have come a long way since Independence and made a name for ourselves globally.

The President has talked about inclusivity in our society, and while there are significant achievements that we can be happy about, there are some areas that we can still improve on. I wish to focus on two – our education system and our youth.

Let me first address the issue of Normal (Technical) education. Our education system has evolved from survival to efficiency to ability-driven, both in approach and provision. We have seen how our students have reaped the benefits from our education system and how we have managed to nurture knowledgeable and skilled Singaporeans who are highly-regarded in the workplace.

Skills and knowledge are well-catered for and honed in schools, but more can still be done to ensure that resources are more equitably distributed to non-elite schools or what we used to call "neighbourhood schools", which may not have the kinds of facilities or resources that the elite schools do, partly due to the latter's' strong alumni network and more affluent home backgrounds of the students.

The Ministry of Education has announced the setting up of two new specialised schools for Normal (Technical) students. While the details are yet to be revealed, I hope that the introduction of these two new schools will not mean that all Normal (Technical) students will be taken out of mainstream schools and "hot-housed" separately. I fear this goes against the essence of inclusivity and integration in our society.

Page: 479

Sir, what I believe can be done instead is to ensure that teachers teaching Normal (Technical) students in mainstream schools are specially trained, specifically in motivational and counselling skills. When I was a secondary school teacher about a decade ago, I had the opportunity to teach Mathematics to a Secondary 3 Normal (Technical) class. After a few attempts at teaching them about integer powers and how to write an index notation for integer powers, I decided that they did not quite care how much I knew, until they knew how much I really cared for them. So that was when I decided to put the books aside and focus on them as individuals.

I talked to them, got to know about their home backgrounds, their problems and their aspirations. But there were times when I felt that it was very difficult because I had 38 students in the class, and I felt that I did not quite know how to make them trust me and open up to me. If only I had been specially trained to work with them a little better, I think I could have been a better teacher to them.

It seems that little has changed from then until now. Some of my in-service students in NIE – these are current school teachers – have shared with me that it is not easy to get teachers to teach Normal (Technical) classes in schools. Those who do find that they are somewhat overwhelmed with the amount of effort and skills that are required of them.

Sir, I hope that Normal (Technical) classes in mainstream schools can be made somewhat smaller; more specially-trained teachers can be deployed to these classes, while more relevant courses and programmes, such as computer graphic animation or digital music, for instance, can be introduced to them so that we can maximise their potential during their school years. This is pretty much like what we did for the Gifted Education Programme back then. If we could do it for the top end of the academic stream, why not for the other end?

Sir, let me now address the issue of values-driven education. The MOE has also announced its re-emphasis on values-driven education in schools. This is indeed a step in the right direction, and some of my fellow parliamentarians have agreed and talked about this at length.

However, while its intent is noble, its implementation probably needs a little bit more careful planning. As we know, values are not as easily taught as they are caught. When teachers have to complete teaching the syllabi in order to adequately prepare students for high-stakes examinations, and when they are appraised based on the performance of their students in these examinations, we cannot quite blame teachers for focusing on examination-based achievements and drilling for examinations. Teachers may substitute lessons meant for Civics and Moral Education to teach Mathematics or Science, or force fit a National Education message in a lesson just so they can fulfill the requirement to do so. Through all these, students may form the impression that CME or NE is probably not as important as examination-based subjects.

I hope that the MOE will work closely with teachers to adequately address how values-driven education can be more effectively weaved into the curricula, and that it is not an additional item for appraisal or additional workload for teachers.

I also hope that MOE can look into how we can focus less on summative assessment modes, such as high-stakes examinations, and more on formative assessment modes, such as project-based learning and evaluation of the learning process rather than just the outcomes, so that we can provide a more holistic and sufficient learning environment in schools where students do not need to turn to tuition in order to succeed.

Page: 480

We need to bring our students' learning away from tuition teachers and tuition centres that tend to regard education as a commodity and back into our schools where teachers are there because they see education as a necessity where, to them, teaching is a calling, where they care and they believe that they can lead and inspire our students. We need to re-align the value of learning to the learning of values, skills and knowledge, and not learning for grades.

Sir, having proposed these, I must also urge partners to work with schools and the MOE. In particular, parents have a very significant role to play – to be more involved in their children's education, to work with teachers to ensure that the education their children receive in schools is complemented by a conducive supportive environment at home, and to focus on their children's holistic development and celebrate the learning process, rather than summative grades and examination-based achievements.

Community and industry partners also have a role to play in providing an authentic learning environment for students. Much can be explored and done in this respect, such as providing more opportunities for service learning or internships, for instance, to nurture values such as compassion, resilience and responsibility.

(In English): I will revert to English now. Sir, before I end my speech, please allow me to address what Member Mr Yee Jenn Jong mentioned on Wednesday. He suggested that political education be included in our school curriculum. He also said that our young undergraduates are not politically savvy enough. First of all, in my humble opinion as an educator, the introduction of political education should not precede values, character and citizenship education. Political education is one rather specialised component of citizenship education. As Sir Bernard Crick, a British political theorist, pointed out: citizenship education is defined as a fostering and development of moral and social responsibility, community involvement and political literacy. Hence, if we introduce political education in primary or secondary schools, I fear that it is rather premature. It is akin to teaching simultaneous linear equations before teaching them the BODMAS Rule or the four operations in Mathematics.

In addition, the major opinion by educators and parents in the UK, for instance, is that political education has the tendency to be partisan and that there should not be any politicisation of learning in schools. As for Mr Yee's perception that our young undergraduates are not politically savvy enough, I would urge him to accord them more credit and interact with them more because they are not as apathetic as he thinks.

On that note, Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion and thank the House in earnest.

The Senior Minister of State for Information, Communications and the Arts and the Environment and Water Resources (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion. Recently, MICA celebrated the opening of the Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall on the 100th Anniversary of the 1911 Xin Hai Revolution. Some Singaporeans asked, "What is the significance of this event to Singapore, and why are we celebrating it?" There are many, many reasons why this is an important event to us. I would like to share with the House one of the reasons – a personal one.

In one of the many meetings that Sun Yat Sen had in Singapore – organising the support for his cause – he noted that women were absent and he directed the community leaders to focus on "educating your women, empowering your women". Several years later, the community leaders heeded his call, started several schools, and they hired a young lady from China to head Nanyang Girls' High School. The lady stayed on and dedicated 40 years of her service to educating women, including my mother. This lady was my grandmother. So, without Sun Yat Sen, the school might not have existed, my grandmother might not be here and, clearly, my existence would have been in doubt. The significance of the 1911 revolution is that it marked a new beginning for Chinese women – liberated Chinese women from having to suffer the excruciating pain of binding their feet, being subjects of their father, their husbands and, when they are widowed, the sons. It sets the historical context of the development of women in Singapore, which is the main theme of my speech.

Page: 483

I was born a year after the Independence of Singapore, and it is therefore very convenient for me to draw on my personal life story to illustrate the development of the social status of women in Singapore. The Singapore that I was born in was one with serious economic problem – high unemployment rate. Only four out of 10 women could read. Forty percent of the girls born in the 1950s did not receive any formal education, twice the rate for boys. It clearly showed that parents were placing more emphasis on educating their sons, at the expense, sometimes, of their daughters. Many older Singaporeans remember growing up in families where the womenfolk are always around: mothers stayed at home to look after their children and unmarried daughters stayed at home to take care of the siblings and household chores until they are married off.

By the time I am ready for school in the early 1970s, my cohort, the post-Independence cohort, had been more fortunate. In the early 1970s, nine out of 10 girls received formal primary education. Had I been in a co-ed school, out of a class of 40, 20 would be boys and 20 would be girls.

Over the next 12 years, six out of 10 in my cohort went on to attain secondary level education, and two out of 10 went on to attain pre-U and poly education. Literacy rate improved significantly from six in 10 to nine in 10 in one generation. I was fortunate to be the one in 10 that had gone on to university.

The gender ratio in the university was slightly in favour of the men. In a typical class of 20, there would be nine female students versus 11 male students. In my class in the School of Accountancy, I remembered having 17 female students and three male students. So, clearly, women were doing well in school, and families were supportive of their education. Women in Singapore already had an equal chance of getting into university as men in the 1980s. Notably, the post-Independence generation of women delayed their marriage by two years, compared to their sisters a decade ago.

The picture in the workplace, however, tells a very different story. I started working from the 1990s. I got married a couple of years later at 25, which happened to be the median age of marriage for women then. By then, only seven out of 10 women remained in the workforce. Three out 10 had left the workforce by the time they married.

Surveys have shown that gender-ratio equality in the workplace is maintained only at the entry level. In other words, we had the same number of men and women only at the entry level. As we move up the corporate hierarchy, the number of women is significantly fewer than men. We are under-represented three to eight – three women to eight men – in the senior positions. Similarly, women only made up 7% of boardroom positions in listed companies in Singapore.

Page: 484

There is no doubt that women are dropping out of the workforce earlier than men, and are not progressing as far as the men. The trend is not surprising. The share of family responsibilities rests disproportionately on women. Women are expected to undertake the primary role in caring for the husband, children and the parents. And whilst we are fortunate to have the support of domestic helpers, women are often expected to be the one making career adjustments to suit the family circumstances. Many chose to take a slower pace in their career, some chose to drop out of the workforce completely.

The younger generation of women, on the other hand, is postponing marriage and parenthood. With good education, good jobs, women are excelling in the workplace and enjoying financial independence and satisfaction from their jobs. They are delaying the drudgery of marriage, if it means having to sacrifice their lifestyle choices.

Should we, as a Government and a society, do something about it? From a society viewpoint, the well-educated and capable women form a rich pool of talents. Societies that educate and empower their women progress at a faster pace than those who do not. So we want our educated women to contribute meaningfully in the workplace. At the same time, we want our younger women to marry and have children. We are all familiar with the problems of low fertility rate and ageing population. So we should, as a Government, as a society, do something about it. But what do the women in Singapore want us to do about it?

Firstly, women today do not want to see marriage and parenthood as a steep cliff from which they take the leap of faith. They do not wish to see employers writing them off once baby is on the way; neither do they wish to rely solely on the promise of their spouses to provide for them for the rest of their lives. They want a workplace where employers, recognising the multiple roles that they play, manage their career with flexibility over their life phases. A female employee choosing to work part-time when she is caring for a young child should not be excluded from training opportunities and career progression opportunities. Ambitious women want a comeback after slowing down for a few years.

Although more employers are now introducing flexible work arrangements in recent years − about 35% of them do offer some flexible work arrangements, women want to see more companies offering more options – more part-time work opportunities, flexible work hours and tele-commuting arrangements. Employers – one in four – who give time-off for staff to attend to unplanned personal urgent matters get a thumbs-up.

I strongly encourage more employers to introduce flexible work arrangement, especially given the current shortage in manpower. We have a pool of 30% to 40% untapped "womanpower". We need favourable employment conditions and practices to keep as many people meaningfully employed as possible.

Many women whom I have met told me about their concerns for their children's education, and I would add to Minister Heng's list of 20 speakers now, who will speak on this issue. They have found the system to be highly competitive and felt compelled to take time off for their children's education. Many education systems in Asia are competitive but, in Singapore, competition comes early with a high-stake examination – PSLE – at 12 years old. Peer pressure cause parents to head towards award-winning enrichment centres, tutors and coaches for their children.

Page: 485

Sir, having spent three years in MOE, I would, more often than not, explain to them the policy considerations. They generally understand the policy intent but, nevertheless, find it emotionally very tiring to cope with it. Coaching their children for PSLE is probably one of the most frequent reasons for working mothers to take leave from work. I know because I used to do it. Does pressure from our education system affect fertility rate? Well, Sir, I certainly do not think that it helps, if our mothers are staying up at night thinking about it.

Secondly, many women who have stopped work want to re-enter the workforce when their children have grown older or when family circumstances have stabilised. We should help them. Many women hesitate about the first step of going back to work due to lack of confidence or relevant skills. The Government should do more in training and getting them ready for work. The typical "place and train" scheme needs to be augmented by pre-placement courses to help build up their confidence. Many women also need to transit into full-time work again. Having responsibilities at home, they prefer jobs near their homes, or more flexible work arrangements for a start. We need companies to offer transition arrangements, such as part-time work, "internship" for mature workers, perhaps, to help transit women into the fast-paced jobs that they were used to. Job-matching programmes targeted specifically at women should be encouraged.

Thirdly, on a different note, many women have asked for more Government policies to be child-centric, rather than family-centric. Women I spoke to uphold marriage as an important institution in the society and believe that the family structure of having an intact family – parents who are married to one another – is the optimal one to raise a child. But the reality that they see is that the number of single-parent families in Singapore is rising and we are struck by the predicaments that they face.

There are three groups of single mothers that many women and men have spoken up for. The first is the Singaporean divorcee mothers. The second is the widowed and divorced non-Singaporean mothers with Singaporean children. And the third is women who bore children out of wedlock. These women and their children are caught by our policies. And one key problem is housing. The lack of subsidisied accommodation has become the albatross around their necks. They have to fork out market rent each month, leaving them with very little to pay for food and other needs of the children. More often than not, the women and their children are caught in a poverty trap. The Government should re-think our policies and move towards a child-centric one. They are Singaporean and we should help raise them as one of our own, in a stable home environment.

Sir, the 1911 revolution liberalised Chinese women. Fifty years on, under the PAP Government, girls were educated, women could work and get equal pay as men, polygamy was abolished and married women were given legal status. Women today have equal opportunity in education as men. They have choices. The more the society facilitates women in assuming the multiple roles that they have – as an employee, as a wife, as a mother, as a daughter – the less we will have to choose one over the other. Young women of today want to have a good career, financial independence and a happy family. Yes, we want it all, just like the men do.

Sir, while women have made significant progress in Singapore, we clearly can do better. I urge all to help each and every woman realise their potential, so that our daughters and our granddaughters can and will scale greater heights in Singapore and, as stated in the President's Address, "enjoy meaningful and fulfilling lives". [Applause.]

Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol) : Sir, I rise in strong support of the President's speech and his emphasis on inclusive and quality growth. Sir, I was in Barcelona in June this year and I was surprised to see that the Catalonia Square, which is a main square in the centre of Barcelona, was being occupied by many protesters. Of course, it was filled with a row of toilets as well. And when I asked how long have they been there, the answer was "months". I was actually transiting – I was going to Bilbao – and when I arrived in Bilbao, I asked them what was going on. And they said, "Well, even in Bilbao itself, our main square has been occupied." So, what is going on, and it is all young people? The answer was, "Well, you see, the unemployment rate of young people in Spain has reached an unprecedented rate." Twenty-odd percent is considered common; in some places, it is even 50%-odd, and many of these are well-schooled, well-educated. So, I asked, "What do they do and how long do you think this will last?" The answer was, looking up in the sky, "wa meng ti" – in their own language.

Sir, obviously that movement itself has spread to now what is known as the "Occupy Wall Street" movement. The sense of income inequality, of lack of jobs, lack of opportunities, unfairness, food, water, fuel insecurity, global inflation and the ballooning world population that has crossed the 7-billion mark this year, truly stress-tests our old-world order, which is falling apart. Is Singapore agile enough to pass this test, or even take advantage of the morphing world order? Our future depends on what we have built up yesterday, what we decide and do today and, of course, our future quotient. To succeed in the "new normal" at the global and national levels, leaders in the private, public and citizen sectors need to switch from thinking about incremental changes to transformational, systemic change.

For sure, we cannot resolve problems using the same paradigms that created it in the first place. So, when President Tan spoke about inclusive, quality growth, it tugged at my heartstrings. Not only because it has been my pet parliamentary subject for the last five years, but also because it holds the promise of this urgently needed transformational change.

Sir, we may think of economic growth as giving us the wherewithal to "enjoy life", but Singaporeans have reflected that it is not a sufficient condition for the sense of progress or well-being. One may ask, "Is 14.5% GDP growth not good enough?"

Sir, if growth means more foreign workers to ride the crest of an uptake in the economy, it also implies more crowded public transport, higher housing prices and competitions in schools. It means a congested city at short notice, ignoring the human considerations and time needed to adjust. Counting the happy moments of the day against the unhappy ones for your average Shenton Way worker would mean taking into account the following: waiting for the third or fourth train to get to work; jostling with hordes of people in the station to make it to work on time; thinking where to find an affordable meal with a seat to enjoy; feeling trapped in the best-paying jobs one can get to afford the mortgages; keeping up with one's peers in the rat race of life; and struggling how to fit family time into this picture.

Page: 487

Reading the papers, this worker would also feel anxious about their future, as the world faces the threat of another protracted downturn. Today, the people "occupying" Wall Street are saying that they have lost faith in the "market" and the absence of the "invisible hand" in its promise to serve the needs of the common man.

So it is important that this Government aims well beyond the GDP measure of growth, which is only a snapshot of a country's domestic output at a point in time. It does not give the granularity we need to understand, first, if the growth properly trickles down to that of the common man; and, second, whether it contributes to his or her sense of progress or well-being.

But, Sir, I would also like to note that this is not the first time that the subject of GDP vs GNH or other development index has been invoked in this House. In fact, for years in this House, myself and a few other Members had repeatedly called for a new measurement matrix of our national progress. So I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the other Members 各方英雄"ge fang ying xiong" in this House for joining this call. However, I have also learnt over the years that, sometimes, it is not just the frontbenchers who do not agree with the views of the backbenchers, but that we must back it up with considered alternative solutions and come together with the Government as one team, one Singapore team, sit on the same side of the table, to walk the talk, and not just talk and talk. So, I rise to give a few suggestions on how to operationalise it, and I will be happy to work on it if the Government accepts my proposal.

Recent in-depth studies of quality growth point to the need to recognise at least three other types of "capital", in addition to the economic capital, and these, together, will sharpen the country's external competitiveness, and simultaneously foster the cohesiveness and well-being of the society.

They are, first, personal capital which refers to a person's philosophy or value system, mental and physical health, hopes and aspirations. The second: social capital, which refers to one's social connectedness and the community's wellness. And, third, environmental capital, which refers to environmental security, food, biodiversity, and so on. In short, it is time for our national measurement system to move from measuring just one aspect of the national asset and our economic capital to an integrated, holistic measure of all four "capitals".

Well-being is no fluffy stuff. In fact, people and communities with a higher sense of well-being are more adaptable and resilient. These are the exact future readiness traits needed for a more volatile and fast-moving world. And if growth in Singapore is conceptualised in the manner set out, we can continue to ensure our citizens have little affinity to the disillusioned "Occupy Wall Street" protesters. We can continue to buck the trend and progress.

So how do we do this? I have a few suggestions. One, I suggest that we compile the "The People First Report". Instead of deciding on what are some of the priorities of the people, perhaps we should commission a report that draws on the best minds at the conceptualisation level, and invite all citizen inputs at the measurement level to this question: what do Singaporeans really want at the four levels of "capital" and well-being that I have described earlier? And it should take a life-cycle approach and a segmented orientation as outlined in the President's speech. A school child may have a very different concern from an adult, from a homemaker and, of course, that of a senior citizen. And, clearly, the report must incorporate the challenges and opportunities of being an ageing society. It should also end with some notion of a new social compact that incorporates the roles that citizens, communities and businesses can and should play alongside with the Government. This should be sign-posted and measurable indices drawn up to tell us if we are on- or off-target so that we can adjust our strategies along the way.

Page: 488

Taking a leaf from the recently published Report on the Measurement of Economic Performance and Social Progress by Nobel Laureates, Professors Joseph Stiglitz, Amartya Sen and Jean-Paul Fitoussi, they have incorporated ideas about achieving economic well-being, social capital, developing human capital, counting environmental impact and quality of life domains that matter to the ordinary person. And if we can arrive at a solid document, it can feed into discussions of our budgetary objectives. It will force a whole-of-Government approach to public policy as different domains will have to work towards these higher-order goals. And if we are able to come up with a compelling vision, I think that the business and people sectors will be equally energised and inspired to achieve the same goals in their own special way.

At this point, I would like to highlight a breed of organisations that directly achieve the sort of inclusive, quality growth that we aspire. And, of course, these are the social enterprises and innovators. For example, we have a restaurant chain called Eighteen Chefs. It was started by an ex-offender, Mr Benny Seto. Benny got out of prison and wanted a second chance and a shot at the Singapore Dream. But he found that he was still in prison when the doors of employment were shut tight on him. He loves to eat, so he decided to pack his bag and head towards Jamie Oliver's Restaurant 15. Jamie Oliver is a young British celebrity chef, and Restaurant 15 gives ex-offenders and youths-at-risk a shot at a job and to learn how to run their own restaurants. Benny worked hard and started Eighteen Chefs, mimicking Restaurant 15. In so doing, he has now created a chain of restaurants that has jobs for both normal people and ex-offenders. He helps to close the gaps between them, allows the marginalised to be perceived as able, contributing citizens, and live a full life as a dignified Singaporean. Imagine the trickle-down effects of this on his or her family, how his neighbours and community look on him, and how this precious citizen can contribute to our GDP again.

Sir, there are many Bennys in this sector and in many industries. In the UK, the development of the third sector has now pervaded all fields and all walks of life, and social enterprise takes the form of big serious businesses that attempt to solve national concerns. In Singapore, check out our very young Singaporean scientist, Dr Adrian Yeo, who won the Don Quixote Fund Award for his water-treatment technology. He wants to effect a sustainable change in how the world lives, and people like him should be given every opportunity to turn their clean technologies and dreams into ongoing business concerns. But what we need is a policy framework at the heart of Government that supports individuals and companies like these across the boundaries of the typical business and social sectors.

So, perhaps, one, we could recognise the need for a third sector and grant start-ups, or donations, or even preferential treatments, grow it like a strategic industry because it is strategic through our inclusive and quality growth objective. And allow hybrid regulations to operate within this sector so that they can grow faster and also remove the obstacles that are currently in place.

Secondly, we could also augment Government procurement systems to take into account the social and environmental impact of their vendors. Today, with this new Parliament, people would have new expectations of us. They hope our Parliament and our Government will be better and more effective than before.

Mr Speaker, some MPs cited Shakespeare, and some cited Confucius. I am not a learned man. I want to tell you a mystical story. This is the story of the magical lamp, the genie and the three wishes. There were two men, one by the name Gouxin (勾心) and one by the name Doujiao (斗角). Guxin and Doujiao were arch enemies. One day, they were walking along the beach and they found this magic lamp. They rubbed it and the genie came out. The genie said, "The two of you can have three wishes." After some argument, they decided that Gouxin would have two wishes and Doujiao just one. Doujiao said, "My wish is simple. I will just get double what Gouxin will get! Therefore one wish is enough for me. Whatever he has, I want double that." The genie said, "Fine! I can fulfil your wish." Then the genie asked Gouxin, "What is your wish?" Gouxin said, "OK. I want all the best things in the world." Genie said, "Fine!" and boom, he had everything. Gouxin was very happy. He had everything in the world. Yet, when he saw Doujiao, he became not so happy. Why? He was happy because he had all these good things but Doujiao would have double what he had. "I have all these good things but Doujiao will have more than me!" The genie said, "You can have your last wish now. Think carefully about it." Gouxin thought, "What should be my next wish?" Then he told the genie, "I have thought about it. My wish is, 'please beat me half dead'!" You see, these two people came across the genie and they can have three wishes. This is a good thing. However, because of their bad nature – Gouxin Doujiao (meaning in-fighting), one ended up dead and one half-dead. A good thing turned into a bad thing.

I think this GE is perhaps like this story. Singaporeans found a magical lamp. Unfortunately for this lamp, no matter how you rub it, no genie comes out. Under this circumstance, Singaporeans hope the next five years will be better. We want the future to be better, but we cannot rely on the genie to fulfil our wishes. I feel that, for this new Parliament and the new Government, the responsibility to Singaporeans will be to treasure today's Singapore, because it is very difficult to achieve what we have done so far. At the same time, we must understand there is a long way ahead of us and it will become more treacherous. This better future will not be achieved through words, but through our actions.

I sincerely hope the Opposition can change their usual ways. Just like Mr Seng Han Thong has pointed out many times in Parliament, the Opposition has only views but no alternative suggestions. I hope the Opposition can change. They should not criticise every time they see policies people do not like or take the credit for polices that people like. This kind of opposition is like a "Gouxin Doujiao" opposition, not beneficial for Singapore's long-term development.

At the same time, I hope our new Government can also change the usual ways of doing things. We will continue to be a good Government. At the same time, we need to improve communication with our people. Before, we serve the people silently, humbly and sincerely; but for the sake of Singapore, we cannot do that anymore. It is not that we will boast about the good things we did for the people, but that we want people to know why and what we did for our people. I hope, in the future, the Opposition can be a very good Opposition and the Government a very good Government. Let us put Singapore's interests first. Only by doing this can we have a bright future, even though we do not have the genie.

(In English): Sir, a new Parliament and a new Government bring new aspirations as outlined by President Tan in his Address. The line that caught my attention was about building an inclusive nation that we can all be proud of. The journey of building a nation is long and one without any end. And my preoccupation, what I lose sleep about is: how do we stay competitive in the future? How do we stay cohesive as a people in the future? And how do we create and build a better Singapore for Singaporeans?

After the GE, a friend told me. He said, "Swee Say, I feel sorry for you. I feel sorry for the Government." I said, "Why so?" He said, "Everything that you do, if they are unpopular, the Opposition would just keep criticising you. Anything the Government does that is popular and welcomed by people, the Opposition members will then just claim the credits." I said, "What gave you this impression?" "Oh! Just go to the blog. Go to social media." So, for example, I was told, I have not seen it myself, that one Workers' Party Member, I think on his blog or Facebook, he explained the reason why bus fare went up by only 1%, why Minister Khaw Boon Wan decided to build more HDB flats and Minister for Education decided to expand the capacity for university education. He said, "All these is because of the Opposition. As a result, the Government has become more responsive."

I was not sure whether I should believe what he said because I have not seen it myself. But today, I must say that I believe in it about three quarters, because today I need not have to go to any Facebook or new media to find out what he said. Today, I heard it personally from Member Mr Low Thia Khiang, because Mr Low in his address earlier basically claimed credit for everything, all the positive changes that have taken place since the General Elections. But I told my friend, I said, "Look, it doesn't really matter how the Opposition parties play with politics", because I said, "At the end of the day we are in politics not to play with politics because what is at stake is the future of the country and the life of people." I said that as far as we are concerned, there are two things we need to do.

One is to be hard-headed in making sure that we will remain competitive as an economy for a long time to come. Joblessness is not something to be taken lightly. In 1988, during the Asian Financial Crisis, unemployment at that time was about 3% to 4%. I was asked this question as a union leader: Why is NTUC so concerned about 3% to 4% unemployment rate compared to many countries. I told the reporter who asked this, "Unemployment could be 3%, 4% but to the person who is unemployed, unemployment rate is 100%." People who are unemployed are under tremendous stress. In 1999, I was in France. The unemployed workers in France on welfare, unemployment benefits, were on strike. They were on strike because they were demanding for holiday allowance. Of course, many people criticised these unemployed workers and said, "Look, you are unemployed, you are receiving unemployment benefits, and yet you dare to ask for holiday allowance." And the response from the leaders of the striking force was, "Do you know that we unemployed live a life a lot more stressful than those who are employed because every day we wake up with no idea how to spend the day and there is no end to that kind of suffering." Therefore, speaking as a member of the NTUC, as a member of the Labour Movement, I would urge this House not to take growth lightly, not to take joblessness lightly.

Page: 492

In the USA, for a long time, there is a line they repeat, as a half-hearted joke. USA is a land of Cash, Wonder and Hope. Why Cash? It refers to Johnny Cash. Why Wonder? It refers to Stevie Wonder. Why Hope? It refers to Bob Hope. Later on, as the years went by, Johnny Cash passed away, Bob Hope passed away and, recently, Steve Jobs passed away. So, today the slogan in USA is: USA today is a country of no Cash, no Hope and no Jobs. USA is today going through a jobless growth. The IMF recently has just said that unemployment is now a developed country's problem. In other words, it is not just restricted to the USA. Many developed economies are facing the same problem.

Singapore is, today, in terms of per capita income, in the same rank as the OECD countries. We should not take our job creation in Singapore lightly. Remember, our workers talk about higher cost of living, and are pushing for real wage increase. But just imagine if a worker has no job, even if you can push for 10% wage increase, as far as he is concerned, his wage increase of 10% of zero is still zero. In other words, there is no way an unemployed person can cope with any higher cost of living. And this is the reason why the labour movement, joined forces with our tripartite partners to ensure, to urge, to mobilise the ground to enhance our competitiveness.

Two to three days ago, the hon. Member Mr Gerald Giam, if I am not wrong, criticised the Government and the Labour Movement for urging our workers to pursue "cheaper, better and faster". I think I explained in this House before and I do not mind saying again that there is a big difference between "cheaper, better, faster" workers versus "cheaper, better, faster" products and services. What the NTUC, what the tripartite partners are calling for, is to pursue "cheaper, better, faster" products and services, pursue a "cheaper, better, faster" economy, not a "cheaper, better, faster" workforce.

On Facebook, right now, there is a company that said it offers two out of three of the following services − "cheap, better and fast". Only two out of three, and not three out of three. What it means is that if it is cheap and good, then it cannot be fast. Cheap and fast, but it cannot be good. Good and fast, but it cannot be cheap. So, two out of three. Some Facebook friends then asked me, "Mr Lim, why are you asking for all three, three out of three? Isn't that unrealistic?"

A company in Singapore produces precision optics. They have eight production lines – if I can recall correctly. Each and every of these production lines is designed by engineers from Germany. So, the engineers in Germany will design the production lines, bring them to Singapore, install them here. Eight of the lines were done that way. Our Singapore engineers operated the lines for a few years. One day, they convinced the management that why not allow us Singapore engineers in Singapore to design the ninth line. After more than one year of persuasion, finally approval was given. Our Singapore engineers designed the line and I saw it myself when I went to the factory for a visit. The line was designed cheaper than the eight lines designed by the German engineer, is able to produce better products, better quality, lower reject rates. But, more importantly, it produces output at a pace that is much faster than the German line. The line designed by the Singapore engineers is what we called a "cheaper, better and faster" line.

Page: 493

Our challenge is not to keep doubting ourselves – that why are we pushing workers to be cheaper, better, faster? Whether three out of three is possible? Instead, we should ask ourselves: If we are not able to achieve cheaper, better, faster products and services, will there be a future for the Singapore economy, for the Singapore workers?

On the issue of foreign workers: it is a tough subject. The labour movement has to take a position on foreign workers. We have always mentioned that foreign workers are not our enemy because foreign workers are here to perform a useful role, a supporting role. My colleague Yeo Guat Kwang, a couple of weeks ago, made a statement that we should train, we should require the skills upgrading of foreign workers for them to work in Singapore. Many people criticised him, saying "How can you advocate the upgrading of foreign workers?", including I think Member Yaw Shin Leong. I think it is important that we ask ourselves: are we better off having two unskilled foreign workers in Singapore or are we better off having one skilled foreign worker in Singapore? If the one skilled foreign worker can do the job of two unskilled workers, we will be able to reduce the social cost of foreign workers in Singapore and yet at the same time take advantage of their contribution to the Singapore economy.

Likewise, what about foreign PMEs? The labour movement lately has been advocating the need to have more protection for our PMEs. But does this mean that the labour movement is advocating a no foreign PME policy? It cannot be. Just yesterday, there was an article in The Wall Street Journal about Rolls Royce, one of the world's leading companies in many areas, including aircraft engines. The article said Rolls Royce is powering ahead in high-wage countries, at a time when their competitors were going for the low-wage countries. And one of the high-wage countries that Rolls Royce believes in is Singapore. They are investing billions of dollars in building the latest factory in Singapore. The factory will be opened sometime next year, but the Chairman and the management are so excited. They invited the unions and the NTUC to visit the plant. I took up the invitation. It will be what I call the factory of the future in Singapore. What they did was to take all the best features from all their factories in other parts of the world, including UK where their headquarters is based, and put them in Singapore. They put all the best practices, all the best ideas here. This factory in Singapore will be handling their most coveted technologies, at the same time using the most advanced production processes not seen in Singapore, not seen in this part of the world, and they will have the best team of people to handle the plant. Guess what? EDB, WDA supported by the NTUC, we are working with Rolls Royce to train 500 people to get ready for the plant. Of course, Rolls Royce cannot just depend on the 500 Singaporeans to run the plant because there are many areas we do not have the experience yet, we do not have the expertise. But what Rolls Royce is doing is to bring the latest technology to Singapore. They will bring the latest expertise to Singapore, but it will go through a process called "glo-calisation". They globalise their operations to Singapore, at the same time they will localise expertise over time here. This is what we are talking about. When the Labour Movement talks about Singapore first, we are not advocating Singaporeans only policy because at the end of the day, that will only hurt us. What we are advocating is a concept of "CORE-calisation". In every sector of the economy, there should be a core of Singaporeans being nurtured to lead the future development of those sectors.

While we are hard-headed in keeping Singapore competitive, I believe we should become more soft-hearted in helping Singaporeans to stay cohesive – to work, live and play together. Food – what Singaporeans are looking for would be cheaper, better, faster food. I am very happy that Dr Vivian Balakrishnan announced the construction of new hawker centres. Housing – what Singaporeans are looking for are cheaper, better, faster public housing. After all the years at EDB, walking around the world to look for investments, I can say that being cheaper, better, faster is the most effective secret weapon of Singapore, and I think we should apply that to the social arena as well.

Mr Speaker, Sir, will we succeed in our vision of building an inclusive nation that we can all be proud of? I would say that there is no guarantee. The future is for us to create and it is still there waiting for us to create it. But I believe that we have a better chance of succeeding if we are prepared to apply whole-heartedly in strong alignment. How can we make this happen? I believe that all of us in this House ought to strive to be political leaders, not politicians.

Mr Low Thia Khiang earlier said that he understood that there are trade-offs in Government policies but he said that the trade-offs of the Government are between the interests of the people and the Government. He even said that we are watching the pay of the Ministers more closely than we look after the interests of the people. Now, to accuse the Singapore Government, the PAP Government, as a team of Ministers, led by the Prime Minister, as individuals who are only interested in our self-interest, and that we come to politics to enrich ourselves, to take care of our interests at the expense of the people − I am at a loss for words to describe my feelings inside.

I came into politics not to enrich myself. I came into politics because in 1992, there was a software transfer project between Singapore and China. I was one of the most fortunate persons in Singapore to have spent about two years working at close range with our former Prime Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew. And I learnt at first-hand how he explained his vision of nation-building to the Chinese leaders. And I say that that is the reason why I entered politics and I am very sure I speak for all my Cabinet Members as well.

Sir, let us not be politicians and keep worrying about votes. Let us be political leaders worrying about the future of Singapore, worrying about the future of Singaporeans. Let us put Singaporeans first, put Singapore first. Not PAP first, not Workers' Party first.

Fifty years from now, many of us in this House will be dead and gone, especially those who are more than 50 years old today. [Laughter.] But remember this: 50 years from now when some of us are dead and gone – by then Singapore would still be less than 100 years old – 96. For a person, 96 is old, about time to say bye-bye. But for a country, 96 still represents a very young nation. What we have to do is not to worry about our personal interests, or the interests of the Party, but let us make sure that Singapore will be a nation that is always progressing, always succeeding because it is the only way for a small nation like Singapore to survive. On that note, Sir, I support the motion in thanking the President for his Address. [Applause.]
